description: Biological factors influencing learning and memory with attention to the findings from both animal and human research.

title: Sleep & Dreaming, Brain & Mind
description: Why and how do humans sleep and dream? This is a survey course presenting a biologically informed approach to sleep and dreaming under both typical and pathological conditions. Format will be primarily lecture, but some discussion and active exercises will also be used.
requisites: (PSYC 110 or PSYC_OX 110 or NBB 201 or ANT 200 or NBB_OX 201 or NBB 301 or BIOL 360) and (QTM 100 or QTM_OX 100) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Primate Social Psychology
description: Recent progress in the field of primate social behavior, particularly the role of cognition in complex social strategies.
requisites: This course requires PSYC 110 or BIOL 142 or BIOL_OX142 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Social Development
description: This course examines key developmental changes between infancy and adolescence in various social domains, including self understanding, moral, & emotional development. Through lecture, in-class assignments, and lively discussions, we will contemplate how social interactions shape human psychology.
requisites: PSYC 111 or PSYC_OX 111 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Human Social Neuroscience
description: Neurobiological substrates supporting human social cognition and behavior. Review and synthesis of relevant research in neuropsychology, psychiatry, neuroimaging, and experimental animal research.

title: Personality Theories
description: Key concepts of several major theories of personality and their application to the study of the individual, along with techniques available for the assessment of personality.

title: Positive Psychology
description: This course explores concepts and research on positive psychology as well as techniques and exercises that enhance well being. Integrates findings from personality psychology, life-span development, cognitive psychology, behavioral economics, biological bases of behavior, and social psychology.
requisites: This course requires QTM100 equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite

title: Psychology of Prejudice
description: This course will explore prejudice and its origins, maintenance, consequences, and interventions-primarily from a social psychological perspective, and with a particular focus on racial prejudice in the United States.
requisites: PSYC 110 or PSYC_OX 110 or PSYC 111 or PSYC_OX 111 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Prerequisite: Psychology 110 or equivalent. An in-depth survey of the brain systems and mechanisms involved in perception, memory, awareness, communication, and other cognitive phenomena.

title: Crime And Criminal Behavior
description: The course will emphasize the psychological factors that contribute to criminal behavior, especially those relating to personality and individual psychodynamics.

title: The Psychology of Evil
description: Examination of evil from a psychological perspective. Focus on in depth analysis of criminal cases, including discussion of current evidence concerning the roots of evil and antidotes to evil.

title: Behavior Modification
description: Use of principles of behavior to enhance human functioning. Application of basic research and theory from experimental psychology to personal, social, and educational problems.

title: The Nature of Evidence
description: In this class we will focus on how scientists come to know what they know, wiht a particular emphasis on the nature of evidence used to answer specific questions and how this is similar to and how it differs from the kinds of evidence used in other fields.

title: The Genetics of Human Behavior
description: In this course we will examine the underlying causes of human behavior and traits, focusing particularly on the use of quantitative and molecular genetic methods (i.e., twin and adoption studies, genome-wide studies) to disentangle genetic and environmental influences.
requisites: QTM 100 or QTM_OX 100 or ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or ISOM 350 or POLS 310 or POLS 310W or MATH_OX 117 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Behavioral Neuroscience
description: This course presents an integrated coverage of work at the intersection of animal behavior, evolution, and cellular/systems neuroscience. The course surveys the major areas of behavioral neuroscience.

title: Neuroeconomics:Decision-Making
description: Students will be introduced to the field of neuroeconomics, which uses neuroscience techniques to understand human decision-making. Students will learn about theoretical approaches to and techniques for studying individual decision-making and how to use this knowledge to make better decisions.
requisites: (ECON 201/ECON_OX 201 and ECON 212/ECON_OX 212) or (NBB 301/BIOL360 and NBB 302/PSYC 353) or PSYC 207 or PSYC 215 or PSYC 309/LING 309 or PSYC 335 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Neuropsychology and Cognition
description: Neuropsychological disorders of memory, attention, perception and awareness, and their relation to the brain and to cognitive models of normal function.

title: Special Topics in Psychology
description: A series of special topics of concern to the discipline of psychology. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Special Topics in Psychology
description: A series of special topics of concern to the discipline of psychology. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Cross Cultural Stu in Psyc Rsh
description: This course is offered by the CIPA Psychology in the UK summer study abroad program, and is taught at University College London. Students will be assigned to either Psychology 386 or 387, commensurate with their demonstrated skills and experience in statistics and methods.

title: Cross Cultural Stu in Psyc Rsh
description: This course is offered by the CIPA Psychology in the UK summer study abroad program, and is taught at University College London. Students will be assigned to either Psychology 386 or 387, commensurate with their demonstrated skills and experience in statistics and methods.

title: Adv.Cross Cult.St.in Psyc.Rsch
description: This course is offered by the Emory College Psychology in the UK summer study abroad program, and is taught at University College London. Students will be assigned to either Psychology 386 or 387, commensurate with their demonstrated skills and experience in statistics and methods.

title: Adv.Cross Cult.St.in Psyc.Rsch
description: This course is offered by the Emory College Psychology in the UK summer study abroad program, and is taught at University College London. Students will be assigned to either Psychology 386 or 387, commensurate with their demonstrated skills and experience in statistics and methods.

title: Child Development in S Pacific
description: One of two courses of the South Pacific Summer Study Abroad Program introducting participating students to child development in Samoa and Vanuatu prior to homestays.

title: Special Topics-Study Abroad
description: Selected topics in Psychology for study abroad courses offered through Emory's Office of International and Summer Programs. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Sci & Pseudoscience In Psyc
description: Critically evaluating pseudoscientific, fringe science, and controversial claims in psychology.

title: Brain & Cognitive Development
description: The course examines developmental changes in brain function and organization linked to different aspects of sensory, language, and non-language cognitive processes during the first three years of life.

title: Sleep and Dreaming
description: Study of the neural mechanisms and phenomenology of sleep and dreaming in humans and other animals as a basis for discussing implications for behavior, cognition, evolution, and related philosophical issues.

title: Psychobio of Visual Perception
description: Theories and research about how the brain interacts with mind in generating perceptions.

title: Adv. Neuroimaging Practicum
description: Students will design and conduct their own fMRI study. Students will learn and apply the basic physics underlying MRI, the biological principles of fMRI, the principles of experimental design, the processing steps associated with data analysis, and the use of available software packages.

title: Brain Imaging
description: Application of imaging technology to the study of brain function and anatomy.

title: Neuropharmacology & Placebo
description: Students will learn about pharmacology and the randomized clinical trials process for psychoactive drugs. The neuroscience of and impact of placebo effects on new psychotherapeutic drug approvals will be studied by reading and writing about the relevant primary literature.
requisites: PSYC 110 or PSYC_OX 110 or BIOL 142 or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Hormones, Brain and Behavior
description: The goal of this course is to explore the hormonal mechanisms underlying behavior in a  peer-oriented environment. We will read and discuss classic and current primary literature.

title: Adv Statistics & Res. Methods
description: This course provides an introduction to advanced statistics and the research questions and designs that require their use. Topics include mediation and moderation in multiple regression, complex ANOVA, data reduction techniques, multivariate ANOVA, advanced regression, and resampling methods.

title: Animal Communication
description: Functions, evolution, ecology, and significance of animal communication systems in a wide taxonomic range, from insects to primates.
requisites: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142WE or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Animal Communication
description: Functions, evolution, ecology, and significance of animal communication systems in a wide taxonomic range, from insects to primates.
requisites: (BIOL 142 and BIOL 142L) or BIOL_OX 142WE or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: The Psychology of Love
description: Focus on discussion of current theory and research about attraction, attachment, love and related phenomena. Includes investigation of romantic and companionate forms of love as they are conceptualized and studied by social scientists across adult development.

title: Hist & Systems of Psychology
description: Prerequisite: senior major or consent of instructor. A survey of the evolution of psychology as a natural science beginning with its origins in philosophy. Systems of psychology considered in detail include structuralism, functionalism, Gestalt psychology, psychoanalysis, and behaviorism.

title: Seminar in Cognitive Processes
description: Selected contemporary problems in memory, language, learning, and thinking. May be repeated when the topic changes.

title: Sem In Conditioning/Learning
description: Selected problems in conditioning and learning covering human and/or animal literature.

title: Adv Topics In Abn Psychology
description: Selected issues in psychopathology theory and research.

title: Adv Topics In Abn Psychology
description: Selected issues in psychopathology theory and research with a writing component.

title: Sem: Developmental Psychology
description: The literature on selected topics related to the development of the young organism, both human and animal.

title: Sem:Personality & Social Psych
description: Selected issues in personality theory and research.

title: Biolog Foundations of Behavior
description: Selected issues in physiological and comparative psychology.

title: Directed Research Study Abrd
description: One of two courses of the South Pacific Summer Study Abroad Program introducing participating students doing supervised developmental research in Samoa and Vanuatu during home stays

title: Honors Program
description: Honors Research Seminar. Enrollment limited to psychology majors invited to participate in the departmental Honors Program.

title: Directed Reading
description: Credit variable. Psychology majors only, registration by permission of faculty supervisor.

title: Directed Research
description: Credit variable. Psychology majors only, registration by permission of faculty supervisor.

title: Introduction to Religion
description: An exploration of diverse ways of being religious (for example, in thought, action, community, and experience) as they are displayed in several traditions and cultures.

title: Intro to Anc't Med Societies
description: Social, anthropological, and cultural aspects of two or more ancient Mediterranean cultures from a comparative perspective.

title: Introduction to Jewish Studies
description: This course introduces students to the various questions, texts, methodologies, and perspectives that constitute the broad field of Jewish Studies. It presumes no prior knowledge of Jewish history, religion or culture.

title: Introduction to Sacred Texts
description: Comparative study of sacred texts in two or more religious traditions; textual authority, canons, primary and secondary texts, types of texts, and the function of sacred texts in religious communities.

title: Special Topics in Religion
description: Variety of subjects pertaining to religion at an introductory level. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Special Topics in Religion
description: Variety of subjects pertaining to religion at an introductory level. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Fresh Sem: Religion
description: Dynamics of inquiry on a focused research topic. Will include discussion, debate, oral and written presentations. Topic varies.

title: Relig & Contemp Experience
description: Religion and contemporary issues of human existence, the role of religion in politics and international conflicts, or the nature of contemporary religious movements such as fundamentalism.

title: Biblical Literature
description: The Hebrew scriptures ("Old Testament"), in translation, examined in their historical setting, and in their roles as sacred texts in Judaism and Christianity.

title: Hist of Religions In America
description: An examination of American religious history and culture from the colonial period to the present.

title: Classic Religious Texts
description: This course will explore classic religious texts in depth, developing skills to interpret sacred, philosophical and ethical works. Social, cultural, and/or philosophical contexts at work will provide interpretive frameworks.

title: Western Religious Traditions
description: This course examines western religions over a significant span of history, special emphasis on interactions between culture and religion and between religions; topic varies.

title: Asian Religious Traditions
description: Thematic study of at least two Asian religious traditions. Thematic emphasis may include relationships of text and context, pilgrimage, gender, epic performance, religious institutions, visual arts, or colonial and post-colonial identities.

title: Greek and Roman Religion
description: Introduction to the religions of the ancient Greek and Roman worlds: ritual types, forms of evidence, and methods of investigation, from the Bronze Age to the early Christian era.

title: African Religions
description: Explores the intricacies and interactions of indigenous, Islamic, and Christian traditions in sub-Saharan Africa. Seeks to challenge assumptions that have long precluded understanding African societies in their own contexts and on their own terms. Readings drawn from multiple disciplines and genres.

title: Introduction to Judaism
description: Explores the rituals and practices of Judaism, placing them in their historical context and examining the theological concepts that underpin them.

title: The Sufi Way
description: This course is about The Sufi Way (Islamic Mysticism or tasawwuf), the Muslim effort to experience God's presence and make society good. It focuses on South Asia (Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, Bangladesh) and the Chishti Order, the region's most popular and influential Sufi community.

title: Hindu Nationalism
description: Hindu nationalism is an ideology that imagines Indian identity as distinctively Hindu. This course will explore this complex worldview over the past two hundred years and explore Hindu nationalism's relationships with anti-colonial resistance, 20th century Nazism, and globalization.

title: Poetry of Gods and Kings
description: This course examines the parallel development of Sanskrit and vernacular poetry in the royal court and religious contexts. Critical historical studies of the political, cultural, and religious landscape of India will support our analysis of the poetry focusing on gods and patronized by kings.

title: Poetry of Gods and Kings
description: This course examines the parallel development of Sanskrit and vernacular poetry in the royal court and religious contexts. Critical historical studies of the political, cultural, and religious landscape of India will support our analysis of the poetry focusing on gods and patronized by kings.

title: The Qur'an
description: This course is an introduction to the Qur'an in translation, from historical and literary perspectives, looking at its content, formal characteristics, language, stylistics, modes of narrative, and its relationship to Jewish, Christian, and Arabian traditions.

title: The Qur'an
description: This course is an introduction to the Qur'an in translation, from historical and literary perspectives, looking at its content, formal characteristics, language, stylistics, modes of narrative, and its relationship to Jewish, Christian, and Arabian traditions.

title: Intro.to Religion and Law
description: This course explores the field of religion and law: how these categories of human experience intersect, and the resulting challenges and opportunities. We will consider theories and methods that scholars and practitioners use to contribute new perspectives to matters impacting nations and people.

title: Performing Arts and Devotion
description: This course investigates meaning and culture of the performing arts in religious contexts and spiritual communities, including Islam, Christianity and Hinduism, and less-widely practices like Javanese Kejawen, Central Asian indigenous animism, Haitian vodou ceremonies, and Inuit traditions.

title: Performing Arts and Devotion
description: This course investigates meaning and culture of the performing arts in religious contexts and spiritual communities, including Islam, Christianity and Hinduism, and less-widely practices like Javanese Kejawen, Central Asian indigenous animism, Haitian vodou ceremonies, and Inuit traditions.

title: Anthropology of the Jews
description: Introduction to Jewish populations and cultures within the framework of four fields of general anthropology: biological, archaeological, cultural, and linguistic.

title: Archaeology and The Bible
description: A careful examination of theory and methodology related to this branch of archaeology with special emphasis on famous discoveries, important sites, and the archaeological/historical background of Biblical events.

title: Special Topics in Religion
description: Variety of subjects pertaining to religion. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Special Topics in Religion
description: Variety of subjects pertaining to religion. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Internship in Religion
description: Variable credit, may be repeated for up to 12 Semester Hours total.

title: Topics Abroad
description: Special topics in religion taken during study abroad program and approved by Emory Department of Religion for equivalent credit. May be repeated when topic varies.

title: Topics Abroad
description: Special topics in religion taken during study abroad program and approved by Emory Department of Religion for equivalent credit. May be repeated when topic varies.

title: Interpreting Religion
description: Critical exploration of philosophical, theological, ethical, and social science theories of religions and methods for the interpretation of religious phenomena.

title: Hindu Traditions
description: Hindu religious traditions from prehistorical times to the eighteenth century, including classical texts, rituals, ethical and social structures, institutions, and theologies.

title: Religions in Colonial India
description: Historical survey of religion in India, 1756 to the present, focusing on the impact of British colonial and post-colonial settings on diverse religions in India and among Indians living abroad.

title: Modern Hinduism
description: Hinduism in the modern period, from the early nineteenth century to the present, focusing on religious communities, rituals, modes of leadership, and the contemporary internationalization of Hinduism.

title: Introduction to Buddhism
description: Introduction to the practices, doctrines, literature and institutions of Buddhism, with particular focus on contemplative practices, ethics and methods of philosophical investigation, narrative traditions, and the transformation of Buddhism across cultures.

title: Tibetan Buddh:Psyc Of Enlightn
description: Introduction to philosophical, psychological, and contemplative dimensions of Tibetan Buddhism.

title: East Asian Buddhism
description: The development of Buddhism in China and Japan, including examination of monasticism, ritual, ideas of Buddhahood, Zen, Pure Land, and Buddhist relations to the state and to other religions.

title: Jews & Judaism in Modern Times
description: Modern Jewish history, society, and thought, with emphasis on religious and secular reformulations of Jewish self-identity.

title: Modern Buddhism
description: This seminar focuses on modern Buddhist history, society, and thought. Issues addressed may include colonization, women's ordination, meditation movements, conversion, eco-Buddhism, immigration, and globalization.

title: Early & Medieval Christianity
description: Christianity from the apostolic period through the Middle Ages, with emphasis on the contribution of major theologians.

title: Protestant Christianity
description: Representative types of modern Christianity, beginning with the Reformation in Germany and concluding with contemporary issues.

title: Modern Catholicism
description: Examination of major social, ethical, and theological issues confronting post-Vatican II Catholicism, including the intellectual and historical roots of contemporary debates.

title: Premodern Islam
description: This course is a survey of the major issues in the history, religion, culture, and civilization of the Islamic world in the pre-modern period.

title: Modern Islam
description: This seminar analyzes the problem of Islam in modern history and focuses on religious responses to major events. Issues may include secularism and Post-Enlightenment modernism, reform movements, and Islamic liberalism.

title: Islamic Law
description: This course studies Islam through a legal lens. We explore the main sources of the Shari'a, and study examples of each in the spheres of ritual, criminal, family, and civil law. We also examine how tensions between law, morality, pragmatism, custom, and politics spur Islamic legal development.

title: Native American Religion
description: Study of several Native American religious traditions in their historical contexts, with a focus on ritual, cosmology, and social life.

title: African American Religion
description: Development of religion among African Americans; trends and tendencies.

title: Psychology of Religion
description: Examination of religious existence and its relation to various aspects of human life by approaches developed in major traditions of psychological study.

title: Religion & Sexuality
description: The relation of sexuality and the sacred in symbolism, attitudes and practice; authentic human communion; and specific problems of sexual ethics.

title: Death & Dying
description: Understanding death through a study of religious attitudes and practices, modern therapies for the dying, ethical issues, and Western and Asian theological perspectives.

title: The Holocaust
description: An analysis of the sociopolitical background and the horror of the Holocaust, followed by the popular as well as the theological responses of the Jewish and Christian communities.

title: Black Love
description: "Explores historical & contemporary notions of love with emphasis on love's powerful & controversial presence/absence in the lives of Black people in the North American context. Readings include religious studies, philosophical, historical, literary, social scientific and neurobiological texts."

title: Black Christian Thought
description: Spiritual transformations involving worship, magic and healing, ritual, and aesthetic performance in Black speech and literature, music, and drama; and spiritual uses of Biblical themes to empower social political movements.

title: Women, Religion & Ethnography
description: Cross-cultural ethnographic study of women's religious lives, including ritual and leadership roles, forms and contexts of religious expression, and negotiations between dominant cultural representations and women's self-representations.

title: Religion and Ecology
description: Historical, philosophical, and ethical relationships between religion and ecology; other dimensions include Eastern thought, ecofeminism, animal rights, and literary nature writers.

title: Tibetan Culture
description: This is an introductory course on Tibetan culture focusing on selected themes and perspectives of Tibetan culture.

title: Culture of Buddhist Tibet
description: Tibet's history, geography, and spiritual legacy produced a unique culture that only recently has come into contact with the West; these three facets will be explored for their impact on Tibetan culture.

title: Religion and the Body
description: An exploration of the body and bodily experience in selected religious traditions. Topics may include: ritual, asceticism, monasticism, healing, gender, sex, diet, birth, and death.

title: Dance & Embodied Knowledge
description: This is a theory-practice course in which we analyze the nature of embodied knowledge and the creative power of performance through twice-weekly discussions of mythologies, art, and theoretical analyses of dance and once-weekly participant performance of the Indian classical dance form of Kuchipudi.

title: Jazz, Spirituality, & Religion
description: Considers common roots of spirituals, blues, and jazz, and surveys historical, cultural, social, and denominational factors that have shaped our perspective on the spiritual capacity of jazz. Focus is on the sacred works, biographies, and implicit theological positions of specific jazz masters.

title: Religious Pluralism in Atlanta
description: An exploration of local religious communities in the metropolitan area, with special emphasis on field research methodologies.

title: Tibetan History
description: This course is intended to present an overview of the history of Tibet in an unbiased format. Beginning with an introduction to Tibet's geography, people, language and religion, students will then study selected events and episodes in the history of Tibet.

title: Rabbinic Judaism
description: Background and emergence of Rabbinic Judaism in 100-500 C.E., its institutions and beliefs: study, law, chosenness, messianic doctrine of god, revelation and prayer.

title: Medieval Jewish Thought
description: Intensive study of a major work on an important theme in medieval Jewish thought such as Maimonides' Guide for the Perplexed, Saadia's Beliefs and Opinions, and medieval Jewish exegesis of the Bible.

title: Modern Jewish Thought
description: Intensive study of a major work, author or movement; or of an important theme in modern Jewish thought, such as Heschel, Buber, reform, religious anthropology.

title: Jewish Legal Thinking
description: The role and methodology of law in Judaism, using difficult problems that arise due to recent advances in medical technology as a paradigm for how legal systems address hard issues.

title: New Testament In Its Context
description: Interpretation of the New Testament in the context of the historical, social, religious, and literary environment of the eastern Mediterranean world during late antiquity.

title: Jesus and the Gospels
description: The study of the New Testament gospels through approximately ten Christian gospels and fragments of gospels written during the first two centuries, including modern studies and debates about the historical Jesus.

title: Paul and his Letters
description: The study of the historical role of Paul, his thinking, the major Pauline theme, as well as the problems faced by the first urban Christians.

title: Gender and Religion
description: Construction of gender, definitions of the roles and status of women and men in a variety of traditions; women's and men's religious lives. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Mystical Thought and Practice
description: Mystical texts, themes, practices, and rituals, focusing on selected mystical authors. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Ethics
description: Analysis of methods and/or texts pertaining to ethical decision-making for individual and social problems such as race, sex/marriage, justice, war, biomedical technology, and environmental pollution. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Ritual and Worship
description: History and present experience of worship or liturgy in various traditions, with a variety of methods, including the study of art, music, and/or architecture. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Theological Reflection
description: Issues in contemporary theology. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Religion and Conflict
description: This theory-practice course asks: How does conflict reveal the character and nature of a religion? How can our conflict resolution practices advance our study of religion? Includes case studies.

title: Religion and Healing
description: Designed to explore the mind/body connection as a paradigm to understand religion and healing. Will examine the role of faith, ritual, prayer, and meditation in various models of healing.

title: Buddhist Philosophy
description: Explores the features that distinguish Buddhist thought from other traditions, as well as the unique tenets of major philosophical movements such as Shravakayana, Mahayana, and Vajrayana.

title: Afghanistan and Central Asia
description: Survey of the history, cultures, and religions of Afghanistan and Central Asia including Tibet from antiquity to modern times. Topics will include the Silk Road, Buddhist, Christian, and Islamic cultures of the religion, and medieval, colonial, and modern history and politics.

title: Religion, Film & Media
description: Narrative films concerned with religious issues and experience; commonalities between the film medium and the performative religious imagination.

title: Special Topics in Religion
description: Variety of subjects pertaining to religion. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Special Topics in Religion
description: Variety of subjects pertaining to religion. Content will vary in successive offerings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Spec.Topics in Religion & Law
description: Through variables such as arts, politics, freedom, race, nd coloniality, this repeatable special topics course will explore various ways in which religion and law intersect and pose questions in political life, social justice struggles, community conversations and spaces, and cultural consciousness.

title: Spec Top:Clas.Text/Rel Thought
description: Study in depth of a problem in classical texts or religious thought. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Spec Top:Clas.Text/Rel Thought
description: Study in depth of a problem in classical texts or religious thought. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Spec Tops: Religious Studies
description: Study in depth of a historical or theoretical problem or tradition. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Confucian Classics
description:
Confucian Classics shaped Chinese literati culture from late antiquity to the early 20th century. The goal of this course is to illustrate the diversity of literary and cultural practices that evolved around Confucius' unique body of writings (551 - 479 BC). Knowledge of Chinese is not necessary.
.

title: Confucian Classics
description: Confucian Classics shaped Chinese literati culture from late antiquity to the early 20th century. The goal of this course is to illustrate the diversity of literary and cultural practices that evolved around Confucius' unique body of writings (551 - 479 BC). Knowledge of Chinese is not necessary.

title: Internship In Religion
description: Applied learning in a supervised work experience utilizing skills related to concentrations in religion, in such areas as community service, education and social work.

title: Islamic West 600-1600
description: Historical and cultural survey of Muslim Spain (al-Andalus) and North Africa through the 16th century. The course focuses on the concept of Convivencia (co-existence) as theorized by modern Spanish and North African historians.

title: Literature & Religion
description: Reading and interpretation of representative major literary works in the perspective of their religious meaning.

title: Literature & Religion
description: Reading and interpretation of representative major literary works in the perspective of their religious meaning.

title: The Cultural Revolution
description: A survey of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966 - 1976). Students will study revolutionary songs, films, and model plays, in addition to the visual and material culture of the period. Students will also stage a performance of Taking Tiger Mountain by Strategy.

title: The Cultural Revolution
description: A survey of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966 - 1976). Students will study revolutionary songs, films, and model plays, in addition to the visual and material culture of the period. Students will also stage a performance of Taking Tiger Mountain by Strategy.

title: Topics Abroad
description: Advanced topic(s) in religion taken during study abroad program and approved by Emory Department of Religion for equivalent credit. May be repeated when topic varies.

title: Topics Abroad
description: Advanced topic(s) in religion taken during study abroad program and approved by Emory Department of Religion for equivalent credit. May be repeated when topic varies.

title: Shiite Islam
description: This course is an introduction to Shiite Islam, including a historical survey with particular attention to the Twelver and Ismaili traditions, showing how Shiism has shaped Islamic history in general.

title: Great Books of Islamic World
description:
This course focuses on famous works of the Islamic world and treats the transmission of knowledge, religious orthodoxy and heresy, the presentation of self, and the theory of love. We will read The Arabian Nights, al-Ghazali's Deliverance from Error, and other works.
.

title: Conquest/Conversion:Latin Amer
description: We will produce a 20-page research paper through scaffolded writing assignments, as well as oral and visual presentations. The course theme addresses how Spanish and Portuguese colonization forced Iberian, Indigenous, and African worlds together in the region that is known today as Latin America.

title: Joint Sem Philosophy/Religion
description: Prerequisite: either Philosophy 358 or one course in religion. The religious and philosophical consciousness in confrontation with each other; investigation of their differing natures and methods; and exploration of their possible contribution to the clarification and solution of problems of mutual concern.

title: Topics in Religion
description: Advanced study of an issue, problem or selection of writings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Topics in Religion
description: Advanced study of an issue, problem or selection of writings. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.

title: Snr Symposium:Critique Of Rlgn
description: Selected topics in religious studies. Required for majors.

title: Snr Symposium:Critique of Rlgn
description: Selected topics in religious studies. Required for majors.

title: Directed Reading (Honors)
description: Independent research for senior major and joint-major students selected to participate in the department's Honors Program.

title: Directed Research
description:
Students conduct directed or supervised research in support of a faculty member's research project or agenda. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty
member is required.

title: Directed Reading
description: Students study, read, and write on a topic under the direction or supervision of a faculty member. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty member is required.

title: Independent Research
description: Students conduct independent research in support of their own research agenda or question with guidance from a faculty member. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty member is required.

title: Elementary Chinese I
description: This is the first of two courses that introduce students to modern Mandarin Chinese. It covers the sound system of Mandarin Chinese and moves on to basic skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and offers an introduction to Chinese culture. For non-heritage students only.

title: Elementary Chinese II
description: This course is the second semester of Elementary Chinese. Speaking, reading, listening, and writing will be learned in a communicative context. Students are expected to participate in class by engaging in interactive activities and reading and writing practices. For non-heritage students only.

title: Elem Chn:  Heritage Speakers
description: This course is designed for students who already possess basic speaking skills of Mandarin Chinese but are not literate in Mandarin Chinese. It will focus on improving students' reading and writing skills.

title: Chinese Language Studies Abrd
description: Placement determined according to proficiency. This course is exclusively for students studying Chinese through an Emory-affiliated summer abroad program. Students learn practical Mandarin Chinese in natural settings. A Chinese martial arts master will also provide instruction twice per week.

title: Elementary Chinese Abroad I
description: This is the first of the two elementary Chinese courses, offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China. Students learn the sound system of Chinese, acquire basic communicative skills in Chinese in listening, speaking, reading, and writing. They also learn aspects of Chinese culture.

title: Elementary Chinese Abroad II
description: This is the second of the two elementary Chinese courses, offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China. It is designed for those who have taken CHN 101 or CHN 111. The course aims to further develop communicative skills in speaking, listening, reading, and writing in Chinese.

title: Freshman Seminar
description: Freshmen only to satisfy GER freshman seminar requirement. Please see website for updated offerings. Course topics have included Foreigners in Imperial China; Mind and Body in China; Shanghai: Lure of the Modern.

title: Intermediate Chinese I
description: This course is designed to help students reach intermediate-level communicative skills, both in spoken and written Chinese, and to establish a solid base for more advanced language learning. For non-heritage speakers only.

title: Intermediate Chinese II
description:
This course provides intermediate-level training in spoken and written Chinese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in CHN 201. Attention is given to complex grammatical patterns, discourse characteristics, and discussions of cultural
topics. For non-heritage speakers only.

title: Interm.CHN for Heritage Spkrs
description: This course is designed for heritage speakers of Mandarin Chinese and is a continuation of CHN 103. The emphasis is on improving students' reading and writing skills. It prepares students for further study at the advanced level.

title: Chinese Calligraphy
description: Students will gain basic knowledge of how to write and appreciate East Asian brush calligraphy. Topics include: materials and tools, structure of characters, history and development of styles, the importance of calligraphy in East Asia, and the basic strokes of standard style.

title: Intermediate Chinese Abroad I
description: This is the first of two intermediate Chinese courses, offered only in Emory's study abroad program in China. It is designed to help students reach intermediate level communicative skills in both spoken and written Chinese by expanding their linguistic and cultural knowledge.

title: Intermediate Chinese Abroad II
description: Offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China, the course provides intermediate level training in spoken and written Chinese in cultural context, based on skills developed in CHN 201 or CHN 211. Attention is given to complex grammatical patterns and discussions of cultural topics.

title: East Asian Calligraphy
description: Studies East Asian calligraphy in artistic, cultural, and historical contexts, starting with the immediate aspects of calligraphy as a traditional art form, and then reaching beyond the classically defined discipline to examine its aesthetic values, intellectual metaphors, and moral criteria.

title: East Asian Calligraphy
description: Studies East Asian calligraphy in artistic, cultural, and historical contexts, starting with the immediate aspects of calligraphy as a traditional art form, and then reaching beyond the classically defined discipline to examine its aesthetic values, intellectual metaphors, and moral criteria.

title: Descript'n & Analysis:Chn Lang
description: An overview of important elements of the Chinese language and its use. Students will gain an understanding of the history of the language, as well as the phonological, semantic, and syntactic structures of modern Chinese. Also examines cultural and social issues surrounding the Chinese language.

title: Chinese:How Hast Thou Changed
description: This course introduces the development of Chinese language from proto Sino-Tibetan roots to modern standard Chinese, and presents the chronological changes in syntax and phonology. We will discuss key historical stages in Chinese developments, and analyze it from the view of linguistics aspects.

title: Chinese:How Hast Thou Changed
description: This course introduces the development of Chinese language from proto Sino-Tibetan roots to modern standard Chinese, and presents the chronological changes in syntax and phonology. We will discuss key historical stages in Chinese developments, and analyze it from the view of linguistics aspects.

title: Chinese Writ. Systems in Asia
description: This course examines the manners and contexts in which the Chinese writing systems interface with other languages and cultures (Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese) and the cultural identities that the Chinese orthographic symbols come to represent at both personal and social levels in and beyond Asia.

title: Intro to East Asian Studies
description: Required for EALC Majors and East Asian Studies Majors and Minors. An interdisciplinary course that introduces students to major topics and methodologies in East Asian Studies, with an emphasis on writing, research, and critical thinking. Themes include history, literature, religion, and the arts.

title: Intro to East Asian Studies
description: Required for EALC Majors and East Asian Studies Majors and Minors. An interdisciplinary course that introduces students to major topics and methodologies in East Asian Studies, with an emphasis on writing, research, and critical thinking. Themes include history, literature, religion, and the arts.

title: East Asia: 1500 to Present
description: This course will emphasize transnational aspects of East Asian history, focusing on how the East Asian international system interacted with Southeast Asia, South Asia, Inner Asia, as well as with Europe and the U.S. from 1500 to the present.

title: Modern China in Film & Fiction
description: This course is an examination of twentieth-century Chinese society through cinematic productions and a critical reading of the writings of major Chinese writers in translation. Emphasis on self and society in a changing culture and the nature and function of literature in modern nation-building.

title: Mod China in Film and Fiction
description: This course is an examination of twentieth-century Chinese society through cinematic productions and a critical reading of the writings of major Chinese writers in translation. Emphasis on self and society in a changing culture and the nature and function of literature in modern nation-building.

title: Lit.in Early & Imperial China
description: This course examines seminal works of Chinese literature from its origins in the first millennium BCE to the eighteenth century. All the readings will be in English translation.

title: Lit. in Early & Imperial China
description: This course examines seminal works of Chinese literature from its origins in the first millennium BCE to the eighteenth century. All the readings will be in English translation.

title: The Heritage of China
description: This course is a general introduction to Chinese history, culture and literary tradition. It is designed to acquaint the students to ideas, institutions, aspects of life, literature and arts that are essential to an educated understanding of the Chinese world.

title: Gendering/Queering China
description: This course offers an introduction to modern Chinese history through the lenses of gender and sexuality. We will consider a broad range of topics, including prostitution, courtship and marriage, legal and medical constructions of sexuality, and the gendered division of labor.

title: Revolutions & Republics: China
description: Spanning the period that covers the First Sino-Japanese War (1895) through present, this course will explore the major transformations reshaping and reinventing cultural, political, and economic life in China through the shifting meanings of "revolution" and "republic."

title: Post-Mao? China After 1976
description: This course introduces students to the history, culture, society, and politics of China since 1976 through an exploration of the continuities and discontinuities knitting pre and post 1976 China.

title: Special Topics in Chinese
description: Study of Chinese language, literature, society, thought, or culture, alone or in conjunction with other literary or cultural trends. Topics to be announced in advance.

title: Special Topics in Chinese
description: Study of Chinese language, literature, society, thought, or culture, alone or in conjunction with other literary or cultural trends. Topics to be announced in advance.

title: Adv Chinese I: Oral/Writ Comm
description: First semester of Advanced Chinese. The course emphasizes advanced reading, grammar, and conversation. Authentic materials are included, such as news articles, television, fiction, and film. Students will learn to read both traditional and simplified characters. For non-heritage students only.

title: Adv Chinese II
description: Students will continue to develop skills in Chinese by reading, discussing, and writing about topics in contemporary China. They will practice expressing their ideas in Chinese and will developan enriched understanding of traditions in Chinese culture  and society. For non-heritage students only.

title: Adv. Chn.for Heritage Speakers
description: An advanced course for heritage learners with emphasis on improving reading and writing abilities. Through reading and discussion of texts on Chinese life, culture, and society, the course enhances students??? overall Chinese proficiency and understanding of the Chinese culture.

title: Adv. Chn.for Heritage Speakers
description: An advanced course for heritage learners with emphasis on improving reading and writing abilities. Through reading and discussion of texts on Chinese life, culture, and society, the course enhances students??? overall Chinese proficiency and understanding of the Chinese culture.

title: Advanced Chinese Abroad I
description: Offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China, the course focuses on developing students' advanced language abilities through reading and discussions of texts on the changing attitudes and values of modern China. Reading of authentic texts and conversationalist skills are stressed.

title: Advanced Chinese Abroad II
description: Offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China, the course aims to develop students' advanced skills in Chinese through reading, discussing, and writing about topics on modern China. Students will develop an enriched understanding of the traditions and changes in Chinese culture.

title: Sem.Study of Chn.Lang.Abroad
description: This course is designated for Chinese language courses taken on Emory approved study abroad programs in Fall or Spring semester. This is a variable credit hours course. Students will be avarded credit hours for this course in the event that they have completed other language courses at the appropriate levels.
requisites: CHN 202 or CHN_OX 202 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Chinese Studies Abroad
description: This course is designated for topics of Chinese studies taken on Emory approved study abroad programs in Fall or Spring semesters. This is a variable credit hours course.

title: Chinese Drama
description: The course is an introduction to traditional Chinese drama, from the13th to the 20th century. We will focus on drama as literature but we will also explore the social, material, and performative dimensions of theater, including modern-day stage adaptations of traditional plays.

title: Chinese Drama
description: The course is an introduction to traditional Chinese drama, from the 13th to the 20th century. We will focus on drama as literature but we will also explore the social, material, and performative dimensions of theater, including modern-day stage adaptations of traditional plays.

title: Chinese Lang,Culture & Soc.
description: Examines the intersection of language, culture, and society in modern China. Investigates the linguistic construction of social identities based on gender, ethnicity, age, power relation, and other factors, and ideologies that shape language use in China and in the global Chinese diaspora.

title: Introduction to Translation
description: This course introduces translation theory and hands-on practice in multiple contexts. It is theoretical, methodological, creative. Students engage in multiple forms of translation (inverse, intra and inter-lingual) and meet regularly both as a whole class and in individual language-specific groups.

title: Business Chinese
description: This course is an introduction to basic written and oral communication skills for business and trade negotiations with Mainland China and Taiwan.

title: Made in China
description: Examines definitions of fundamental concepts such as innovation, individuality, genius, authorship, copying in Chinese history, but also draws on other cultures as points of comparison. Includes hands-on studies of manuscripts and artifacts from the collections of the Rose Library and Carlos Museum.

title: Made in China
description: Examines definitions of fundamental concepts such as innovation, individuality, genius, authorship, copying in Chinese history, but also draws on other cultures as points of comparison. Includes hands-on studies of manuscripts and artifacts from the collections of the Rose Library and Carlos Museum.

title: The Stories of Chinese Objects
description: This course studies Chinese cultural history through the lens of artifacts, including paintings, calligraphies, porcelains, bronzewares, costumes. Methods in archeology, anthropology and literary criticism will be applied to illustrate ideas, tastes and technologies that shape Chinese social life.

title: The Stories of Chinese Objects
description: This course studies Chinese cultural history through the lens of artifacts, including paintings, calligraphies, porcelains, bronzewares, costumes. Methods in archeology, anthropology and literary criticism will be applied to illustrate ideas, tastes and technologies that shape Chinese social life.

title: The Political Economy of China
description: This course covers the economic and political systems in the People's Republic of China. It first presents a history of their coevolution, and then examines different sectors in depth, including the opportunities and challenges involved, for Chinese leadership, people, and the world.
requisites: (ECON 101 or ECON_OX 101 or FIN 201) and (ECON 112 or ECON_OX 112) or equivalent transfer credit  as prerequisite.

title: Lit & Cult Late Imperial China
description: This course offers an introduction to the culture and literature of late imperial China. We will discuss a wide selection of literary works from the late 16th to 18th centuries as a prism to reflect on the broader intellectual, social, and cultural history of the period.

title: Lit & Cult Late Imperial China
description: This course offers an introduction to the culture and literature of late imperial China. We will discuss a wide selection of literary works from the late 16th to 18th centuries as a prism to reflect on the broader intellectual, social, and cultural history of the period.

title: Noodle Narratives/Silk Road
description: There are unmistakable similarities between Italian and Chinese cultures regarding the noodle. In fact, the noodle evokes family traditions, rituals, symbolism, and emotional connection in both cultures. Our class explores how identity, assimilation and cultural integration are manifested in food.

title: Noodle Narratives/Silk Road
description: There are unmistakable similarities between Italian and Chinese cultures regarding the noodle. In fact, the noodle evokes family traditions, rituals, symbolism, and emotional connection in both cultures. Our class explores how identity, assimilation and cultural integration are manifested in food.

title: Confucian Classics
description:
Confucian Classics shaped Chinese literati culture from late antiquity to the early 20th century. The goal of this course is to illustrate the diversity of literary and cultural practices that evolved around Confucius' unique body of writings (551 - 479 BC). Knowledge of Chinese is not necessary.
.

title: Confucian Classics
description: Confucian Classics shaped Chinese literati culture from late antiquity to the early 20th century. The goal of this course is to illustrate the diversity of literary and cultural practices that evolved around Confucius' unique body of writings (551 - 479 BC). Knowledge of Chinese is not necessary.

title: The Soundscapes of China
description: From high-pitched voices in Peking opera, classical zither, the drum tower in Beijing, numerous dialects spoken (and sung) to online rap competitions, China is full of wonderful sounds. Using comparative and transmedia approaches, this course offers a comprehensive introduction to these phenomena.

title: The Soundscapes of China
description: From high-pitched voices in Peking opera, classical zither, the drum tower in Beijing, numerous dialects spoken (and sung) to online rap competitions, China is full of wonderful sounds. Using comparative and transmedia approaches, this course offers a comprehensive introduction to these phenomena.

title: Topics in Chinese Studies
description: Study of Chinese language, literature, thought or culture, alone or in conjunction with other literary or cultural trends. Topics to be announced in advance.

title: Topics in Chinese Studies
description: Study of Chinese language, literature, thought or culture, alone or in conjunction with other literary or cultural trends. Topics to be announced in advance.

title: Storytelling Italy and China
description: The course explores the rich novella traditions that developed in Italy and China from late medieval to early modern period. It investigates similarities and divergences between the two traditions, including shifting conceptions of literature, ethical norms, religious beliefs, and gender ideals.

title: Storytelling Italy and China
description: The course explores the rich novella traditions that developed in Italy and China from late medieval to early modern period. It investigates similarities and divergences between the two traditions, including shifting conceptions of literature, ethical norms, religious beliefs, and gender ideals.

title: The Cultural Revolution
description: A survey of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966 - 1976). Students will study revolutionary songs, films, and model plays, in addition to the visual and material culture of the period. Students will also stage a performance of Taking Tiger Mountain by Strategy.

title: The Cultural Revolution
description: A survey of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (1966 - 1976). Students will study revolutionary songs, films, and model plays, in addition to the visual and material culture of the period. Students will also stage a performance of Taking Tiger Mountain by Strategy.

title: Chinese Peer Mentors
description: The course will train students selected by the Department of REALC to serve as Chinese peer mentors for CHN 101,102, 201, or 202. The course is "permission only". The department will interview the students and choose the qualified candidate. The mentors should be Chinese native speakers.

title: Screening China
description: The course explores the history and development of Chinese cinema. It discusses "film in China" and "China in film" by focusing on the function of cinema and reconfigurations of time, space, gender, and history in Chinese films under different historical conditions since the early twentieth century.

title: Adv.Readings in Modern Chn.I
description: Conducted in Chinese, this course focuses on readings and discussion of authentic reading material. The goal is to develop students' knowledge of Chinese culture and ability to understand and use Chinese at a more advanced level. This course is designed for non-heritage track students only.

title: Adv Readings in Modern Chn I
description: Conducted in Chinese, this course focuses on readings and discussion of authentic reading material. The goal is to develop students' knowledge of Chinese culture and ability to understand and use Chinese at a more advanced level. This course is designed for non-heritage track students only.

title: Adv Readings in Modern Chn II
description: This course focuses on readings and discussion of material from contemporary works of Chinese literature in conjunction with the movies that are based upon them; reading of Chinese newspapers and viewing TV programs. Class is conducted in Chinese. For non-heritage speakers only.

title: Adv Readings in Modern Chn II
description: This course focuses on readings and discussion of material from contemporary works of Chinese literature in conjunction with the movies that are based upon them; reading of Chinese newspapers and viewing TV programs. Class is conducted in Chinese. For non-heritage speakers only.

title: Adv.High CHN for Heritage Spkr
description: This is a post-advanced course for Chinese heritage speakers. Through close reading and intensive writing on major social issues of contemporary China, it aims to further enhance students' Chinese language proficiency and deepen their understanding of the Chinese society beyond the advanced level.

title: Adv.High CHN for Heritage Spkr
description: This is a post-advanced course for Chinese heritage speakers. Through close reading and intensive writing on major social issues of contemporary China, it aims to further enhance students' Chinese language proficiency and deepen their understanding of the Chinese society beyond the advanced level.

title: Contemp. Chinese Literature
description: This course enhances students' Chinese proficiency at the advanced level and understanding of the Chinese society through close reading and discussion of expository writings and short fictional pieces. Prerequisites: CHN402 for students in the non-heritage track; CHN303 in the heritage track.

title: Intro to Classical Chinese
description: Students will read selections of philosophical and literary texts in Classical Chinese and acquire knowledge of Classical Chinese grammar and lexicon. The course is for students who have taken CHN401 and can be taken in place of CHN402 to fulfill the language requirement for the Chinese major.

title: Adv.Read.Mod.Chinese Abroad I
description: Offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China, the course focuses on readings and discussions of authentic texts from a variety of genres including social, political, journalistic texts and important works on literature. It aims to enhance language skills at more advanced levels.

title: Adv.Read.Mod.Chinese Abroad II
description: Offered only in Emory's summer study abroad program in China, the course focuses on readings and discussions of authentic texts from contemporary Chinese literature, Chinese newspapers, internet, and TV programs. Acquisition of written style Chinese is stressed in this course.

title: Reading Illness in Mod. China
description: This course focuses on literary and media productions of illness to help understand modern Chinese conceptualization of body, mind and humanity. Students will learn to analyze how such diseases as AIDS, cancer, and mental issues are represented in the Chinese context. Course is conducted in Chinese

title: Food and Culture in East Asia
description: In this course, we will place food under analytic scrutiny and explore the variegated histories of food in East Asia. We will interrogate the different ways of imagining, understanding, and defining Asian foods and explore how human relationships to food in East Asia have changed over time.

title: Seminar in East Asian Studies
description: A capstone seminar required for East Asian Studies and EALC majors.

title: Seminar in East Asian Studies
description: A capstone seminar required for East Asian Studies and EALC majors.

title: Honors Chinese I
description: Permission only, discretion of instructor. See requirements for Honors Degree.

title: Chinese Language Internship
description: Variable credit. Permission only, discretion of instructor. Provides students of Chinese an opportunity to use their Chinese language skills outside the classroom, exposing them to a variety of native speakers in a number of different situations. Students will be assigned to a number of tasks: interpreting at appointments with social workers, doctors, dentists, welfare workers, food and clothing banks and at job interviews, as well as assisting customers and doing Chinese word processing in Chinese travel agencies and other types of businesses. Students are advised to be flexible as different tasks may be assigned each day.

title: Freshmen Seminar
description: Focus on selected topics in East Asian studies.

title: Chinese Calligraphy
description: Students will gain basic knowledge of how to write and appreciate East Asian brush calligraphy. Topics include: materials and tools, structure of characters, history and development of styles, the importance of calligraphy in East Asia, and the basic strokes of standard style.

title: Asian Religious Traditions
description: Thematic study of at least two Asian religious traditions. Thematic emphasis may include relationships of text and context, pilgrimage, gender, epic performance, religious institutions, visual arts, or colonial and post-colonial identities.

title: East Asian Calligraphy
description: Studies East Asian calligraphy in artistic, cultural, and historical contexts, starting with the immediate aspects of calligraphy as a traditional art form, and then reaching beyond the classically defined discipline to examine its aesthetic values, intellectual metaphors, and moral criteria.

title: East Asian Calligraphy
description: Studies East Asian calligraphy in artistic, cultural, and historical contexts, starting with the immediate aspects of calligraphy as a traditional art form, and then reaching beyond the classically defined discipline to examine its aesthetic values, intellectual metaphors, and moral criteria.

title: Food Media & Transnatl Culture
description: Discussion-based course examining contemporary food media from and about Asian culinary traditions. Topics include global Asian culture, Asian America, diaspora, media circulation, race, and ethnicity.

title: Food Media & Transnatl Culture
description: Discussion-based course examining contemporary food media from and about Asian culinary traditions. Topics include global Asian culture, Asian America, diaspora, media circulation, race, and ethnicity.

title: Asian American History
description: This course introduces students to the history of people of Asian ancestry in the United States, including immigrants, students, professionals, and refugees from East Asia, South Asia, and Southeast Asia. Thematically, it investigates timely issues facing the Asian American community today.

title: Chinese:How Hast Thou Changed
description: This course introduces the development of Chinese language from proto Sino-Tibetan roots to modern standard Chinese, and presents the chronological changes in syntax and phonology. We will discuss key historical stages in Chinese developments, and analyze it from the view of linguistics aspects.

title: Chinese:How Hast Thou Changed
description: This course introduces the development of Chinese language from proto Sino-Tibetan roots to modern standard Chinese, and presents the chronological changes in syntax and phonology. We will discuss key historical stages in Chinese developments, and analyze it from the view of linguistics aspects.

title: Chinese Writ. Systems in Asia
description: This course examines the manners and contexts in which the Chinese writing systems interface with other languages and cultures (Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese) and the cultural identities that the Chinese orthographic symbols come to represent at both personal and social levels in and beyond Asia.

title: Intro to East Asian Studies
description: Required for EALC Majors and East Asian Studies Majors and Minors. An interdisciplinary course that introduces students to major topics and methodologies in East Asian Studies, with an emphasis on writing, research, and critical thinking. Themes include history, literature, religion, and the arts.

title: Intro to East Asian Studies
description: Required for EALC Majors and East Asian Studies Majors and Minors. An interdisciplinary course that introduces students to major topics and methodologies in East Asian Studies, with an emphasis on writing, research, and critical thinking. Themes include history, literature, religion, and the arts.

title: East Asia: 1500 to Present
description: This course will emphasize transnational aspects of East Asian history, focusing on how the East Asian international system interacted with Southeast Asia, South Asia, Inner Asia, as well as with Europe and the U.S. from 1500 to the present.

title: Asian-American Drama
description: This course introduces selected contemporary theater works centering Asian American artists in theater history, theory, and criticism.

title: Asian-American Drama
description: This course introduces selected contemporary theater works centering Asian American artists in theater history, theory, and criticism.

title: Intro to Japanese Culture
description: This course explores various aspects of life and society in Japan, including writing, gender, memory and history, geography and the environment, aesthetics, and the formation of national identity.

title: Modern China in Film & Fiction
description: This course is an examination of twentieth-century Chinese society through cinematic productions and a critical reading of the writings of major Chinese writers in translation. Emphasis on self and society in a changing culture and the nature and function of literature in modern nation-building.

Emphasis on self and society in a changing culture and the nature and function of literature in modern nation-building.

description: This course examines seminal works of Chinese literature from its origins in the first millennium BCE to the eighteenth century. All the readings will be in English translation.

title: Introduction to Korean History
description: This course is designed as a foundation course on Korean history, preparing students for other Korean history courses, both pre-modern and modern, as well as students' individual research on Korean past. It surveys the major events and topics in Korean history from ancient times to the modern era.

title: Introduction to Korean History
description: This course is designed as a foundation course on Korean history, preparing students for other Korean history courses, both pre-modern and modern, as well as students' individual research on Korean past. It surveys the major events and topics in Korean history from ancient times to the modern era.

title: Nature and Culture in Japan
description: We examine the interaction between the human and natural world in Japanese cultural and scientific history by looking at maps, literature, scriptures, visual media, and current journalism.

title: Making of Modern Korea
description: By drawing on a wide range of materials across various disciplines the course aims to provide a broad and coherent picture of the history of modern Korea since the late 19th century to the contemporary period.

title: Political Change in Korea
description: This course explores the historical dynamics of political change in Korea since the establishment of the First Republic up to the current period, the many factors that shaped its political trajectory and democratization, and the key issues that have defined South Korean politics to this day.

title: Revolutions & Republics: China
description: Spanning the period that covers the First Sino-Japanese War (1895) through present, this course will explore the major transformations reshaping and reinventing cultural, political, and economic life in China through the shifting meanings of "revolution" and "republic."

description: This course introduces students to the history, culture, society, and politics of China since 1976 through an exploration of the continuities and discontinuities knitting pre and post 1976 China.

title: Spec.Top.in East Asian Studies
description: Study of East Asian literature, history, society, thought, or culture, alone or in conjunction with other literary or cultural trends. Topics to be announced in advance.

title: Spec.Top.in East Asian Studies
description: Study of East Asian literature, history, society, thought, or culture, alone or in conjunction with other literary or cultural trends. Topics to be announced in advance.

title: East Asian Art & Culture
description: Introduction to the arts of China, Korea, and Japan, from Neolithic to contemporary periods. Topics include calligraphy, painting, sculpture, architecture, bronze, and ceramic, highlighting both cross-cultural exchanges and the distinctive identities of each tradition.

title: Reading Literature in Japanese
description: This class helps students develop the skills necessary to read Japanese-language texts without the aid of an instructor. Assignments emphasize vocabulary building and kanji recognition, strategies for decoding complex sentence structures, and the nuances of language and literary style.

title: East Asian Buddhism
description: The development of Buddhism in China and Japan, including examination of monasticism, ritual, ideas of Buddhahood, Zen, Pure Land, and Buddhist relations to the state and to other religions.

title: Chinese Drama
description: The course is an introduction to traditional Chinese drama, from the13th to the 20th century. We will focus on drama as literature but we will also explore the social, material, and performative dimensions of theater, including modern-day stage adaptations of traditional plays.

title: Chinese Drama
description: The course is an introduction to traditional Chinese drama, from the 13th to the 20th century. We will focus on drama as literature but we will also explore the social, material, and performative dimensions of theater, including modern-day stage adaptations of traditional plays.

title: Politics of Southeast Asia
description: Suggested prerequisite: POLS 110 or 120. Intro to the contemporary politics of SE Asia. Focus on capitalist developing countries of the region - Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore. Approach is comparative, with focus on democratization, economic growth, and environmental issues.

title: Politics of Japan & East Asia
description: Suggested prerequisite: Political Science 110 or 120. Examines politics of contemporary Japan, with stress on political bases of Japanese economic growth and in comparison with other East Asian economic successes (e.g., Taiwan, South Korea).

title: Cross-Cult Iss in Mental Hlth
description: Focuses on cultural approaches to mental health and illness.

title: Chinese Lang,Culture & Soc.
description: Examines the intersection of language, culture, and society in modern China. Investigates the linguistic construction of social identities based on gender, ethnicity, age, power relation, and other factors, and ideologies that shape language use in China and in the global Chinese diaspora.

title: Religion Health and Healing
description: This class explores issues such as what makes for a healthy self or person, the role of religious practices and belief in healing, and the relationship of body and mind.

title: Asia in American Imagination
description: This course examines the history of US relations with East Asia, Southeast Asia, and South Asia by focusing on the changing American views of Asians. Topics will include US expansion across the Pacific, US wars in Asia, Asian immigration to the US, and decolonization and capitalist development.

title: Topics in Korean Cinema
description: In this course, we will analyze films and engage with critical theory through Korean film. We will discuss genre, narrative/visual strategies, and representation of a national cinema tradition while thinking about global visual cultures. Topics may vary by semester. Includes weekly film screening.

title: Samurai,Shogun & Women Warrior
description: An examination of the image of the warrior in Japan through literature and its effect on many areas of Japanese culture, including philosophy, literary history, religion, music, and the visual arts. Emphasis is on the exploration of primary texts.

title: Lit & Visual Culture in Japan
description: An exploration of the complex interactions between written texts and the visual arts in Japan from the classical era to the present. Discussion will include prose, poetry, printing, picture scrolls, calligraphy, woodblock prints, and film.

title: Mod Jpn Lit In Engl Translatn
description: Surveys Japanese literature from the mid-19th century to the present. Introduces the nature and range of literary genres as they developed in the context of Japan's confrontation with modernity. The course opens for discussion issues in contemporary literary theory in order to understand aspects of Japanese literature and culture, such as gender, nationalism, intertextuality, Orientalism, and identity. Texts are in English translation.

title: Mod Jpn Lit in Engl Translatn
description: Surveys Japanese literature from the mid-19th century to the present. Introduces the nature and range of literary genres as they developed in the context of Japan's confrontation with modernity. The course opens for discussion issues in contemporary literary theory in order to understand aspects of Japanese literature and culture, such as gender, nationalism, intertextuality, Orientalism, and identity. Texts are in English translation.

title: Lit & Cult Late Imperial China
description: This course offers an introduction to the culture and literature of late imperial China. We will discuss a wide selection of literary works from the late 16th to 18th centuries as a prism to reflect on the broader intellectual, social, and cultural history of the period.

title: Lit & Cult Late Imperial China
description: This course offers an introduction to the culture and literature of late imperial China. We will discuss a wide selection of literary works from the late 16th to 18th centuries as a prism to reflect on the broader intellectual, social, and cultural history of the period.

title: Japanese Modern Women Writers
description: This course familiarizes students with the multiplicity of the female voices that (re-)emerged in Japanese literature from the Meiji period (beginning 1868) to the late twentieth century. Texts are in English translation.

title: Japanese Modern Women Writers
description: This course familiarizes students with the multiplicity of the female voices that (re-)emerged in Japanese literature from the Meiji period (beginning 1868) to the late twentieth century. Texts are in English translation.

title: Chinese Music & Culture
description: Open to all students regardless of Chinese language ability, basic language skills will be taught. This course examines the historical, social, and individual aspects of Chinese musical cultures through the use of English and Chinese sources.

title: Premodern Japan
description: A survey of ancient, medieval, and early modern Japan through the 1850s. Topics include Japan's relations with the outside world; the rise of the imperial institution; and the evolution of aristocratic, samurai, and townspeople's culture.

title: East Asian Musical Cultures
description: This course explores how music creates differences between countries in East Asia and, at the same time, ties them together to create a distinct East Asian identity.

title: History of Modern Japan
description: A survey of modern and contemporary Japan (1850s-present) focusing on major historical changes and on their repercussions on the lives of individual citizens. Topics include nation building, historical memory, and the meaning of progress.

title: The Political Economy of China
description: This course covers the economic and political systems in the People's Republic of China. It first presents a history of their coevolution, and then examines different sectors in depth, including the opportunities and challenges involved, for Chinese leadership, people, and the world.
requisites: (ECON 101 or ECON_OX 101 or FIN 201) and (ECON 112 or ECON_OX 112) or equivalent transfer credit  as prerequisite.
