description: This course considers visual, written, and musical representations of the Spanish Civil War and its aftermath. Topics include the ethics of art in wartime; the uses of propaganda; women's activism; history and memory.

title: Childhood in Hispanic Culture
description: This course examines representations of childhood and adolescence in Spanish, Latin American, and Latinx literature and film, focusing on the ways that discourses for and about children are used to idealize or critique the cultures that produced them.

title: The New Novella
description: In recent years, the novella has become very popular in Spanish-language fiction. In this course, we read and analyze the works of several rising stars on the Latin American and Spanish literary scene, with attention to their use of this in-between genre.

title: Intercultural Internship
description: Students receive credit for a semester-long internship with an organization that serves Spanish speakers. Class time invites students to reflect critically on experience using concepts common to intercultural communication and global workplace dynamics. Instructor permission required.
requisites: One 300 level SPAN or SPAN_OX course or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Introduction to Translation
description: This course introduces translation theory and hands-on practice in multiple contexts. It is theoretical, methodological, creative. Students engage in multiple forms of translation (inverse, intra and inter-lingual) and meet regularly both as a whole class and in individual language-specific groups.

title: Studying Language and Society
description: This course presents different methodologies for the study of topics related to the Spanish language and Hispanic cultures, with a particular focus on discourse analysis techniques. Students will design and complete their own research project on a topic of their preference.

title: Hispanic Utopias/Dystopias
description: The concepts of utopia and dystopia represent opposing sides of the same coin. This course examines speculative fictions and activist projects through which Spanish, Latin American and Latinx authors, filmmakers, and artists critique the political and social conditions in which they live.

title: Shepherds, Witches, and Nature
description: This course offers an overview of one of the most popular genres in early modern (1500-1800) fiction, the pastoral. Students read various works from the Hispanic and Lusophone worlds, focusing on issues of coloniality, gender, race, and identity to better comprehend Europe's colonial endeavors.

title: Shepherds, Witches, and Nature
description: This course offers an overview of one of the most popular genres in early modern (1500-1800) fiction, the pastoral. Students read various works from the Hispanic and Lusophone worlds, focusing on issues of coloniality, gender, race, and identity to better comprehend Europe's colonial endeavors.

title: Islamic West 600-1600
description: Historical and cultural survey of Muslim Spain (al-Andalus) and North Africa through the 16th century. The course focuses on the concept of Convivencia (co-existence) as theorized by modern Spanish and North African historians.

title: Topics in Language and Culture
description: Advanced study of a topic related to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world. Students may take multiple SPAN 385 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Topics in Language and Culture
description: Advanced study of a topic related to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world, with a strong writing component. Students may take multiple SPAN 385 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: In Translation (Topic)
description: Advanced study of a topic related to the language, discourse,  literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world as seen in English translation.

title: In Translation (Topic)
description: Advanced study of a topic related to the language, discourse,  literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world as seen in English translation, with a strong writing component.

title: Language &Discourse on the Web
description: This course incorporates a general theoretical frame in linguistics, with a specific focus in discourse analysis and pragmatics, and applies it to electronic communications. Students will develop an intercultural research project by analyzing digital texts in a systematic way

title: Language &Discourse on the Web
description: This course incorporates a general theoretical frame in linguistics, with a specific focus in discourse analysis and pragmatics, and applies it to electronic communications. Students will develop an intercultural research project by analyzing digital texts in a systematic way

title: History of Spanish
description: This course examines the history of the Spanish language in terms of both its structural and sociocultural/political development. Students develop research projects based on questions arising in the course.

title: Hispanic Sociolinguistics
description: This course focuses on the dynamic interaction between language, society, and identity in the contemporary Spanish-speaking word. Students develop research projects based on questions arising in the course.

title: Language and Identity in Span
description: Part of the Iberian Studies Summer Program, this course explores how and why language varies in Spain and how variation and multilingualism relate to competing identities and ideologies. Students conduct surveys, interviews, conversation analyses, and work collaboratively on research projects.

title: Medical Discourse in Latin Am.
description: This course examines how narratives about the body, health, medicine, and well-being are constructed, naturalized, and circulated in Latin America.

title: Topics in Spanish Linguistics
description: Upper-level research seminar on topics of Hispanic linguistics and communication, such as history of the language, bilingualism, or translation. Students may take multiple SPAN 410 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Topics in Spanish Linguistics
description: Upper-level research seminar with a strong writing component on topics of Hispanic linguistics and communication, such as history of the language, bilingualism, or translation. Students may take multiple SPAN 410W courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Translation Theory & Practice
description: This course presents the history and multiple theories of translation, as well as basic methods/techniques and problems of translating between English and Spanish. A portion of class time will be devoted to translation practice and the comparison of multiple translations of a single text.

title: Translation Theory & Practice
description: This course presents the history and multiple theories of translation, as well as basic methods/techniques and problems of translating between English and Spanish. A portion of class time will be devoted to translation practice and the comparison of multiple translations of a single text.

title: Spanish in the US
description: This course provides a descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States, as well as a methodology  for the study of these practices. Special attention is given to the relationship between language and society.

title: Spanish in the US
description: This course provides a descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States, as well as a methodology  for the study of these practices. Special attention is given to the relationship between language and society.

title: Mexican National Cinema
description: This course explores how cinema has commented on and participated in constructing Mexican national identity. Students will acquire a competence in Mexican film history, the ability to speak and write about film analysis in Spanish, and familiarity with critical approaches to Mexican cinema.

title: Mexican National Cinema
description: This course explores how cinema has commented on and participated in constructing Mexican national identity. Students will acquire a competence in Mexican film history, the ability to speak and write about film analysis in Spanish, and familiarity with critical approaches to Mexican cinema.

title: Matza and Tortillas
description: Addresses the historical position and cultural production of Spanish and Latin American Jewry, from medieval Spain to the present. We examine how diasporic Jewish subjects have framed their identity while negotiating the pressures of exile, immigration, antisemitism, and political violence.

title: Madrid, Barcelona, New York
description: Centered on cultural representations of Madrid, Barcelona, and New York - sites of exchange and circulation among Spaniards, Latin Americans, and Latinos - this course asks how real cities are remembered or imagined by those who live, visit, or immigrate there; focus on performance of urban identities.

title: Culture of Human Rights
description: This course explores exchanges between political, legal, and ethical discourses on human rights in Spain and recent cultural texts. The course will focus on select areas in the human rights arena that have gained prominence in post-Franco Spain.

title: Colonial Medicine and Empire
description: This course explores a range of topics and texts related to the theory, practice and experience of medical matters in the Hispanic world of colonial-imperial medicine. Topics may include epidemics; gender and medicine; indigenous medical knowledge; diet and food; and doctors and curander@s.

title: Colonial Medicine and Empire
description: This course explores a range of topics and texts related to the theory, practice and experience of medical matters in the Hispanic world of colonial-imperial medicine. Topics may include epidemics; gender and medicine; indigenous medical knowledge; diet and food; and doctors and curander@s.

title: Family Portraits
description: This course, taught in Spanish, explores Latin American and Latinx cultural production that uses the family to represent and interrogate questions of cultural identity and transculturation, colonial encounters, abolitionism, nation-building, political repression and historical agency.

title: Family Portraits
description: This course, taught in Spanish, explores Latin American and Latinx cultural production that uses the family to represent and interrogate questions of cultural identity and transculturation, colonial encounters, abolitionism, nation-building, political repression and historical agency.

title: Gender in Lat.Am.Crime Fiction
description: This course studies the interplay between gender and genre in Latin American crime fiction and film. We will focus work by women artists and on representations of women and LGBT characters.

title: Gender in Lat.Am.Crime Fiction
description: This course studies the interplay between gender and genre in Latin American crime fiction and film. We will focus work by women artists and on representations of women and LGBT characters.

title: Epic and Empire
description: This course examines narratives from the Hispanic and Lusophone worlds through the prism of empire and coloniality. Students reflect on the differences between early modern and modern colonialism, the origins of racialized discourses, and the role of literature in framing the history of a nation.

title: Epic and Empire
description: This course examines narratives from the Hispanic and Lusophone worlds through the prism of empire and coloniality. Students reflect on the differences between early modern and modern colonialism, the origins of racialized discourses, and the role of literature in framing the history of a nation.

title: Otherness and Coloniality
description: This course offers an overview of Hispanic and Lusophone literature through the notion of Otherness. It discusses how people were classified according to their place of origin, skin color, gender norms, faiths, and languages, and how marginalized individuals resisted those classificatory systems.

title: Otherness and Coloniality
description: This course offers an overview of Hispanic and Lusophone literature through the notion of Otherness. It discusses how people were classified according to their place of origin, skin color, gender norms, faiths, and languages, and how marginalized individuals resisted those classificatory systems.

title: Workshop on Creative Writing
description: Advanced level workshop focusing on one or more genres of creative writing such as fiction, drama, or poetry, with attention to Spanish-language literary traditions.

title: Topics in Hispanic Culture
description: Upper-level research seminar on topics related to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world. Students may take multiple SPAN 485 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Topics in Hispanic Culture
description: Upper-level research seminar with a strong writing component on topics related to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world. Students may take multiple SPAN 485W courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Honors
description: Fall semester component of the Honors Program. Student and faculty adviser meet regularly to discuss the syllabus agreed upon at the beginning of the term and evaluate progress in research/writing. Spanish 495A does not count as one of the 400-level seminars required for the major.

title: Supervised Reading
description: Advanced individual research on a topic in language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Hispanic world over the course of a semester, supervised by a departmental faculty member.

title: Elementary Portuguese I
description: The first half of a yearlong introductory course designed to train students to understand, speak, read, and write Portuguese.

title: Elementary Portuguese II
description: The second half of a yearlong introductory course designed to train students to understand, speak, read, and write Portuguese.

title: Portuguese for Span Speakers
description: Builds oral proficiency and increases knowledge of Portuguese, Lusophone African, and Brazilian cultures through discussion, listening, reading, and writing on topics pertaining to current events and literature.

title: Port.for Speakers Roman Lang.
description: PORT 111 is an intensive course for students with little or no preparation in the language, but are Spanish speakers (or of another Romance Language). It stresses the fundamental skills of understanding, speaking, reading, and also writing. Diverse aspects of Brazilian culture will be presented.
requisites: SPAN 212 or SPAN_OX 212 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Port.for Roman Lang.Speakers
description:
PORT 114 is an intensive course for students with little or no preparation in the
language, but speakers of another Romance Language. It stresses the fundamental
language skills of understanding, speaking, reading and also writing. Aspects of Luso-
African-Brazilian culture will also be presented.
requisites: SPAN 212 or SPAN_OX 212 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Intro.Topics Luso-Afro-Braz.St
description: Introduces students to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Portuguese-speaking world. May be taught in English or Portuguese. Students may take multiple PORT 185 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Intro.Topics Luso-Afro-Braz.St
description: Introduces students to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Portuguese-speaking world. May be taught in English or Portuguese. Students may take multiple PORT 185 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Freshman Seminar
description: Introduction to the study of Brazilian and Portuguese societies through different prisms (race and gender relations, national cinemas, sexuality, evolution of historical discourse, music, and more).

title: Intermediate Portuguese I
description: The first half of a yearlong review, with emphasis on continued development of the four basic linguistic skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) and knowledge of Lusophone cultures and societies.

title: Intermediate Portuguese II
description: The second half of a yearlong review, with emphasis on continued development of the four basic linguistic skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) and knowledge of Lusophone cultures and societies.

title: Port for Reading Comprehension
description: This course, intended for graduate students, introduces fundamental vocabulary, grammar, and comprehension strategies to develop reading ability. No previous knowledge of Portuguese is necessary.

title: Mapping São Paulo:Interm.Port
description: This course aims to further develop communication skills in Portuguese and expand knowledge of Brazilian cultural traditions. The course is designed so as to dialogically interweave the arts and language acquisition. The students will be exposed to a vast array of meaningful artistic productions.
requisites: PORT 102 or PORT 110 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Adv Practice in Portuguese
description: Development of fluency, vocabulary, and advanced grammatical skills through discussion of contemporary Lusophone culture.

title: Mapping Lisbon: Interm.Port.
description: This course aims to further develop communication skills in Portuguese and expand knowledge of Luso-Afro-Braz cultural traditions, playing close attention to Lisbon, as a space of cultural and linguistic artistic encounters. This course is designed to interweave the arts and language acquisition.
requisites: PORT 102 or PORT 110 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Lang Analys&Written Expression
description: Advanced study of grammar and vocabulary, with an emphasis on composition techniques and reading strategies through readings pertinent to the culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.

title: Media and the Lusophone World
description: PORT 250 is a one-credit course in which students follow and discuss current events via critical analysis and discussion of Lusophone media. The focus will be on newspapers and magazines published in the Portuguese-speaking world. Pre-req: PORT 201 or equivalent.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Inter.Topics Luso-Afro-Braz.St
description: Intermediate-level studies of the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Portuguese-speaking world. May be taught in English or Portuguese. Students may take multiple PORT 285 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Inter.Topics Luso-Afro-Braz.St
description: Intermediate-level studies of the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Portuguese-speaking world. May be taught in English or Portuguese. Students may take multiple PORT 285 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Brazilian Texts and Cultures
description: This course examines Brazilian literature and film. Students formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Brazilian Texts and Cultures
description: This course examines Brazilian literature and film. Students formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Portuguese Texts and Cultures
description: This course examines 20th Century Portuguese literature (novels, short-stories and poetry) and cinema (fiction and documentary). Students formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Portuguese Texts and Cultures
description: This course examines 20th Century Portuguese literature (novels, short-stories and poetry) and cinema (fiction and documentary). Students formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Luso-African Texts & Cultures
description: This course primarily examines literary and cinematographic artistic productions of the five African countries whose official language is Portuguese. Students formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Luso-African Texts & Cultures
description: This course primarily examines literary and cinematographic artistic productions of the five African countries whose official language is Portuguese. Students formulate responses in Portuguese to the various themes addressed in the different texts and films, both orally and in writing.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Brazilian Life Narratives
description: This course explores concepts of authorship through the analysis of different kinds of narratives about the self. Readings include works written in different historical periods in Brazil and also from different perspectives of gender, class, and race.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Brazilian Life Narratives
description: This course explores concepts of authorship through the analysis of different kinds of narratives about the self. Readings include works written in different historical periods in Brazil and also from different perspectives of gender, class, and race.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Mapping São Paulo:Adv.Portug.
description: PORT 311 is designed to interweave the arts and language acquisition. The students will be exposed to a vast array of meaningful artistic production, via the literary, performing, and visual arts. Students will further their linguistic competence through extensive practice in writing and speaking.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Mapping Lisbon: Advanced Port.
description: PORT 314 is designed to interweave the arts and language acquisition. The students will be exposed to a vast array of meaningful artistic production, via the literary, performing, and visual arts. The focus will be better understanding Lisbon as a space of artistic encounters.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Brazilian Cultural Imaginaries
description: This course will provide a firm foundation for understanding São Paulo's unique cultural identity in the Americas and for analyzing its history in a Brazilian and global context. The course it is designed to introduce students to key political and economic developmentsthat have influenced contemporary Brazil.

title: Brazilian Cultural Imaginaries
description: This course will provide a firm foundation for understanding São Paulo's unique cultural identity in the Americas and for analyzing its history in a Brazilian and global context. The course it is designed to introduce students to key political and economic developments that have influenced contemporary Brazil.

title: Portuguese Cultural Identities
description: PORT 334 examines Portugal's history, via an analysis of its capital's cultural productions. The course aims to evaluate how major cultural and historic events played a role in the development of the country, as well as to investigate the interconnections between multiple artistic productions.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit  as prerequisite.

title: Portuguese Cultural Identities
description: PORT 334W examines Portugal's history, via an analysis of its capital's cultural productions. The course aims to evaluate how major cultural and historic events played a role in the development of the country, as well as to investigate the interconnections between multiple artistic productions.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit  as prerequisite.

title: Shipwrecks, Gods, and Martyrs
description: This course offers an introduction to Lusophone literature by focusing on the representation of water bodies across different periods. Students consider early modern and modern colonialisms, the emergence of racialized discourses, and how Africans shaped early globalization while resisting slavery.

title: Shipwrecks, Gods, and Martyrs
description: This course offers an introduction to Lusophone literature by focusing on the representation of water bodies across different periods. Students consider early modern and modern colonialisms, the emergence of racialized discourses, and how Africans shaped early globalization while resisting slavery.

title: Topics: Luso-Afro-Braz Studies
description: This is a topics course in which students follow and discuss current events via critical analysis and discussion of Lusophone media. The focus will be on newspapers and magazines published in the Portuguese-speaking world.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics: Luso-Afro-Braz Studies
description: This is a topics course in which students follow and discuss current events via critical analysis and discussion of Lusophone media. The focus will be on newspapers and magazines published in the Portuguese-speaking world.
requisites: PORT 201 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics in Lusophone Culture
description: Upper-level research seminar on topics related to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Lusophone world. Students may take multiple PORT 412 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Topics in Lusophone Culture
description: Upper-level research seminar on topics related to the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Lusophone world. Students may take multiple PORT 412 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Facts and Fictions
description: This course examines travel literature during the early modern period through concepts like positionality, truth, fictionality, contact zones, and agency. Students think about how literary forms and individual perspectives shape narratives about the encounter between different races and cultures.

title: Facts and Fictions
description: This course examines travel literature during the early modern period through concepts like positionality, truth, fictionality, contact zones, and agency. Students think about how literary forms and individual perspectives shape narratives about the encounter between different races and cultures.

title: Directed Senior Project
description: PORT 480 represents the culmination of your academic journey within the Major in Global Portuguese Studies, offering an opportunity for students to synthesize acquired skills and knowledge and reflect on their academic trajectory, under the guidance of a faculty member.

title: Adv.Topics Luso-Afro-Braz.St.
description: Advanced-level studies of the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Portuguese-speaking world. May be taught in English or Portuguese. Students may take multiple SPAN 485 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Adv.Topics Luso-Afro-Braz St.
description: Advanced-level studies of the language, discourse, literature, and/or culture of the Portuguese-speaking world. May be taught in English or Portuguese. Students may take multiple SPAN 485 courses provided that they focus on different topics.

title: Honors Thesis
description: Fall semester component of the Honors Program. Student and faculty advisor meet regularly to discuss the syllabus agreed upon at the beginning of the term and evaluate progress in research/writing. PORT 495A does not count as one of the 400-level seminars required forthe Span/Port major.

title: Supervised Reading
description: Supervised reading in Portuguese.

title: Foundations of Sustainability
description:
This interdisciplinary course explores the challenges of sustainability through social, economic, scientific, and ethical lenses. Through readings from the natural sciences, humanities, and social sciences, it aims to instill integrative and critical thinking about
global environmental problems.

title: Capstone Research
description: A seminar for Sustainability Minors in which capstone research projects and professional development portfolios are completed. Shared readings and project presentations will support broad integration of the economic, environmental, and social dimensions of the minor.

title: Introduction to the Theater
description: A theoretical and practical initiation to theater as a collaborative art. Includes script analysis as well as basic instruction in acting, improvisation, stage design, and play direction.

title: Acting: Fundamentals
description: An introductory course on the principles and practice of the actor's craft.

title: Stagecraft
description: A theoretical and practical introduction to technical theater.

title: Fresh Seminar
description: An introductory seminar on a special topic in theater studies.

title: Theater Practicum
description: A required course for all majors and minors. Students undertake a substantial technical theater responsibility in a Theater Emory production (e.g. light or sound operator, costume crew, running props backstage, etc.)

title: Reading for Performance
description: The close reading of plays with a view to production. Exercises and projects explore how a text emerges in performance from the combined perspectives of actors, directors, designers, and audience.

title: Reading for Performance
description: The close reading of plays with a view to production. Exercises and projects explore how a text emerges in performance from the combined perspectives of actors, directors, designers, and audience.

title: History of Drama and Theater I
description: General history of the world theater and its literature from its origins to the seventeenth century CE through a selection of representative dramatic works. Focuses on historical forces and the influence of actor, staging, and audience

title: History of Drama & Theater II
description: General history of the world theater and its literature from the eighteenth to the twenty-first centuries, focusing on a selection of representative dramatic works, and on the influence of historical forces as well as of actor, staging, and audience.

title: Voice & Diction
description: An overview of voice and diction for actors. Through group exercises and individual instruction, students will learn techniques to achieve proper breath support, vocal production, vocal range, and articulation necessary for stage performance.

title: Movement for the Actor
description: A course designed for the physical actor. This laboratory-focused course will explore and develop a variety of processes unique to the construction of the actor's physical form and coordination.
requisites: THEA 120 or THEA_OX 120 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Principles of Design
description: A theoretical and practical understanding of the process involved in conceiving and executing a stage design and the interrelationship of the various design disciplines.

title: Sound & Lighting Design
description: Sound and Lighting for Public Presentation is focused on the use of Sound and Lighting Principles for all forms of public presentation, including business presentations, theater, film, music, social media and other forms of public and private events.

title: Arts Administration
description:
A lecture/laboratory course on how artists  accomplish their work in the face of changes in values, government mandates, and the economy.
.

title: Directing I
description: A theoretical and practical introduction to the art of staging plays, including script analysis, rehearsal techniques, and presentation of scenes.
requisites: THEA 210 or THEA_OX 210 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite

title: Asian-American Drama
description: This course introduces selected contemporary theater works centering Asian American artists in theater history, theory, and criticism.

title: Asian-American Drama
description: This course introduces selected contemporary theater works centering Asian American artists in theater history, theory, and criticism.

title: Latine Theater and Performance
description: Latine Theater and Performance examines the emergence of Latine theater and performance as a potent creative and political force in the United States.

title: Latine Theater and Performance
description: Latine Theater and Performance examines the emergence of Latine theater and performance as a potent creative and political force in the United States.

title: African American Theather
description: This course is a survey of African American theather and performance from the early 20th century to the present.

title: African American Theather
description: This course is a survey of African American theather and performance from the early 20th century to the present.

title: Playwriting Workshop
description: Beginning level workshop in playwriting, dramatic writing and/or new play development.

title: Special Topics: Theater
description: Individual courses on special topics in theater at the 200-level. This course may be repeated.

title: Special Topics: Theater
description: Individual courses on special topics in theater at the 200-level. This course may be repeated.

title: Hist of American Drama/Thea
description: A history of the American theater and its plays, including consideration of the actor, staging, audience, and their influence on the development of American theatrical art, performance style, and dramatic literature.

title: 20th Century Music Theater
description: A study of the history and forms of musical theater in America since the turn of the twentieth century.

title: Studies in Period Drama
description: A systematic reading of a group of plays from a major period. Course will focus on the style and historical context of the period.

title: Studies in Genre
description: A systematic reading of plays through dramatic structure as genre, exploring such major forms as tragedy or comedy.

title: Studies in a Major Figure
description: A consideration of the work of a major theatrical figure (dramatist, director, designer).

title: Chinese Drama
description: The course is an introduction to traditional Chinese drama, from the13th to the 20th century. We will focus on drama as literature but we will also explore the social, material, and performative dimensions of theater, including modern-day stage adaptations of traditional plays.

title: Chinese Drama
description: The course is an introduction to traditional Chinese drama, from the 13th to the 20th century. We will focus on drama as literature but we will also explore the social, material, and performative dimensions of theater, including modern-day stage adaptations of traditional plays.

title: Acting: Advanced Scene Work
description: Advanced work on character and relationship through a variety of approaches.
requisites: THEA 223 or THEA  224 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Advanced Topics in Acting
description: A generational change in Theater Studies faculty has required that certain specialty courses, previously closely identified with now-retired instructors, be retained, as we sould wish, but on a topics course rotation that would allow these and other specialties to be taught as a new generation of faculty assembles.
requisites: THEA 223 or THEA 224 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Acting for the Camera
description: This class explores camera acting, including making the transition from stage to screen. Through on-camera exercises, collaborative projects, and screenings, actors will gain the tools they need to perform in a film, web or television shoot with greater confidence, clarity and freedom.
requisites: FILM 376 or THEA 221 or THEA 222 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: The Business of Acting
description: We will discuss the various aspects and obstacles of the business of acting, as well as what to expect and how to be prepared for the professional workplace. Through various discussions and a project we'll also explore how to continue to grow as an actor outside of school.
requisites: THEA 120 or THEA_OX 120 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Costume Design
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of costume design. Includes script analysis from a visual perspective as well as exercises to develop basic design skills.

title: Scenic Design
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of scene design. Includes historical research, script analysis from a visual perspective, and exercises to develop basic design skills.

title: Lighting Design
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of lighting design, including script analysis from a visual perspective as well as classroom and practical exercises.

title: Sound Design
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of sound design, including script analysis and practical exercises in analog and digital sound.

title: Scenic Painting
description: Basic techniques of scenic painting in theater and film in step-by-step projects. The role of the scenic artist. How to communicate with a scenic designer. How to comment constructively on your own work and that of class mates.

title: Arts Writing & Criticism
description: This course introduces students to arts journalism writing and criticism. Students will produce a series of articles in an arts field of their choosing: which can include, but is not limited to, music, dance, theater and visual arts. Students will write reviews for both print and digital formats.

title: Arts Writing & Criticism
description: This course introduces students to arts journalism writing and criticism. Students will produce a series of articles in an arts field of their choosing: which can include, but is not limited to, music, dance, theater and visual arts. Students will write reviews for both print and digital formats.

title: Directing II
description: Prerequisite: Theater 251 or permission of instructor. Includes continued script investigation of a major play, visualization, actor coaching, and analysis of the throughlines of characters in the play.

title: Ensemble
description: An ensemble will intensely research, explore, develop, produce, and perform a collaboratively created bare-bones production. The stylistic focus will vary with each offering. The course is a continuation of skills developed in 100 and 200 level courses.

title: Theater & Ecology
description: Survey of the field of theatre-making that is centered on our ecological crises. Students will examine how drama is being used to bring awareness to environmental issues including extinction, climate change, environmental justice, and sustainability.

title: Theater Workshop in Spanish
description: Taught in Spanish, cross-list between Spanish and Theater Studies. Students deepen their understanding of the Spanish language and Hispanic cultures through script analysis, memorization, character development, in-class exercises, writing assignments, physical and vocal embodiment and performance.

title: Modern Drama
description: Development of modern drama from the late nineteenth century to 1950, including dramatists such as Ibsen, Shaw, Yeats, Synge, O'Neill, and Williams.

title: Topics in Contemporary Drama
description: Selected works of the contemporary theater since 1950, including dramatists such as Beckett, Bond, Fornes, Gems, Pinter, Shepard, and Wilson.

title: Topics in Contemporary Drama
description: Selected works of the contemporary theater since 1950, including dramatists such as Beckett, Bond, Fornes, Gems, Pinter, Shepard, and Wilson.

title: The Self in Performance
description: This course will introduce autobiographical, self-revelatory, and autoethnographic styles of therapeutic theater. Students will create an original autobiographical therapeutic performance using drama therapy techniques.

title: Principles of Drama Therapy
description: An introduction to the field of drama therapy and the theories/principles involved in its practice. An overview of the history of drama therapy, main approaches/theories, and ethical considerations are also included. Students will also engage in experiential drama therapy exercises and reflection.

title: Creating New Works
description: Prerequisites: 200-level theater class or permission of instructor. A workshop for the creation of new works by actors, designers, directors, and writers. Projects may include performances created from improvisation, adaptations of fiction or nonfiction, experimentation with classics, and self-scripted monologues.

title: Intermediate Playwriting
description: Every year. Intermediate level workshop in writing plays.

title: Advanced Playwriting
description: Intensive workshop in writing plays for advanced students.

title: Fieldwork into Performance
description:
This course introduces students to ethnographic fieldwork methods and explores through both case study analysis and class-based ethnodrama processes how applied theater and performance (theater, dance, and spoken word) can be used
to present anthropological insights and ethnographic material.

title: Fieldwork into Performance
description:
This course introduces students to ethnographic fieldwork methods and explores through both case study analysis and class-based ethnodrama processes how applied theater and performance (theater, dance, and spoken word) can be used
to present anthropological insights and ethnographic material.

title: Special Topics
description: Individual courses designed to introduce students to special topics in theater.

title: Special Topics
description: Individual courses designed to introduce students to special topics in theater.

title: Theater Colloquium
description: Spring. workshops, and panel discussions with faculty, guest artists, and alumni, in addition to attendance at arts events.

title: Directed Studies In Theater
description: Variable credit. Prerequisite: permission of department. Special projects, research, and readings under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Aesthetics and Criticism
description: A seminar, capstone to the theater studies major, covering major critical texts that interrogate the nature of the theatrical event.
requisites: (THEA 130 or THEA_OX 130) and THEA 210W and (THEA 215 or THEA_OX 215) and (THEA 216 or THEA_OX 216) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Aesthetics and Criticism
description: A seminar, capstone to the theater studies major, covering major critical texts that interrogate the nature of the theatrical event.
requisites: (THEA 130 or THEA_OX 130) and THEA 210W and (THEA 215 or THEA_OX 215) and (THEA 216 or THEA_OX 216) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Art as Work
description: This course explores the practical, aesthetic, and current issues of the performing arts as they relate to the development of individual artists and the communities that support their work. Focus areas include arts advocacy, grant writing, and the arts as a reflection of contemporary culture.

title: Art as Work
description: This course explores the practical, aesthetic, and current issues of the performing arts as they relate to the development of individual artists and the communities that support their work. Focus areas include arts advocacy, grant writing, and the arts as a reflection of contemporary culture.

title: Performance Techniques
description: Explores skills to effectively and successfully combine singing, facial expression, gestures, interpretation, movement, and interaction with other performers without tension and self-judgment. Repeatable without music major credit. Instructor approval required

title: Advanced Special Topics
description: Individual courses designed to introduce students to special topics in theater at the 400-level.

title: Advanced Special Topics
description: Individual courses designed to introduce students to special topics in theater at the 400-level

title: Honors in Playwriting
description: A tutorial designed primarily to assist honors candidates in preparing their projects. Students will be approved for Honors in Playwriting 494R when the principal focus of the project is the development and/or production of an existing script.

title: Honors Research in Theater
description: This course captures candidates for Honors in Theater Studies's completion of independent honors research.

title: Internship in Theater
description: Theater Studies majors and minors may receive variable credit (1-8 hours) for supervised theater internships approved by the department. Components of an internship include an application, meetings with faculty mentor, and a short paper with documentation of work.

title: Directed Research in Theater
description: Special projects, research, and readings under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Independent Rsch. in Theater
description: A supervised project in any area of theater.

title: Game Theory,Graphs&Math Models
description: Convex sets, linear inequalities, linear programming, two-person games, finite graphs. Applications in management, economics, and behavioral sciences.

title: Transition to Calculus
description: Pre-calculus topics practiced in the context of elementary calculus concepts (limits, derivatives, and antiderivatives). For students who need a review of transcendental functions while learning calculus. Provides a solid foundation for subsequent calculus courses.

title: Calculus I
description: Limits, continuity, derivatives, antiderivatives, the definite integral.
requisites: Students completing MATH 119 or equivalent cannot enroll for MATH 111. For concerns, please contact the Mathematics department.

title: Calculus II
description: Techniques of integration, exponential and logarithm functions, sequences and series, polar coordinates.
requisites: This course requires MATH 111 OR MATH_OX111 OR MATH 115 OR MATH 119 OR MATH_OX119 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Calculus II
description: This class is for freshmen who have earned a 4 or 5 on the AP AB exam, or a 5 on the IB HL exam. Topics include: techniques of integration, exponential and logarithm functions, sequences and series, and polar coordinates.
requisites: This class is for freshmen who have earned a 4 or 5 on the AP AB exam, or a 5 on the IB HL exam. Topics include: techniques of integration, exponential and logarithm functions, sequences and series, and polar coordinates.

title: Life Sciences Calculus II
description: Integration, differential equations, multivariable calculus, and discrete probability and statistics, with an emphasis on applications to biology.
requisites: MATH 111 or MATH 111L or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Intro.Scientific Computing
description: The course introduces Python for Scientific Computing for students who will likely use it in upper-level courses. Students will know how to algorithmically formulate a mathematical problem, solve simple scientific computing problems, visualize data, and consider different programming paradigms.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description:
Rotating topics in math. May be repeated for credit when the topic
varies. Prerequisites and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Fresh Sem: Math
description: Topics will be announced each semester when class is scheduled.

title: Probability & Stats w/Applictn
description: Development and use of mathematical models from probability and statistics with applications.
requisites: This course requires MATH 112 OR MATH_OX112 OR MATH 112Z OR MATH_OX112Z OR MATH 119 OR MATH_OX119 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Adv.Calculus for Data Sciences
description: This course is a short treatment of MATH 112 and 211 with a lab component. It is not appropriate for students who have taken MATH 211. Topics include: advanced integration, Taylor series; and multivariable differentiation, optimization and integration; and applications to statistics and science.
requisites: MATH 111 or MATH 111L or MATH_OX 111 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Adv Calculus (Multivariable)
description: Vectors; multivariable functions; partial derivatives; multiple integrals; vector and scalar fields; Green's and Stokes' theorems; divergence theorem.
requisites: MATH 112 or MATH 112Z or MATH_OX 112 or MATH_OX 112Z or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Differential Equations
description: This is a standard first semester Differential Equations course which covers first and second-order differential equations and systems of differential equations, with an emphasis placed on developing techniques for solving differential equations.
requisites: MATH 112 or MATH 112S or MATH 112Z or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Differential Eqns and Movement
description: Math 212L is a one credit lab that can be taken concurrently with Math 212. Lab activities will be held in a dance studio, primarily led by a dance instructor, with a math instructor participating as well. Lab activities will connect the mathematical content from Math 212 to dance and movement.
requisites: MATH 112 or MATH_OX 112 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Linear Algebra
description: Systems of linear equations, matrices, determinants, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, least-squares.
requisites: MATH 111 or MATH_OX 111 or MATH 112 or MATH_OX 112 or MATH 112Z or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Foundations of Mathematics
description: An introduction to theoretical mathematics. Logic and proofs, operations on sets, induction, relations, functions.
requisites: This course requires MATH 111 as prerequisite AND MATH 112 or MATH_OX112 or MATH 112Z or MATH_OX112Z or equivalent transfer credit.

title: History and Philosophy of Math
description: Topics in the history of mathematics and their philosophical background. Genesis and evolution of ideas in analysis, algebra, geometry, mechanics, foundations. Historical and philosophical aspects of concepts of infinity, mathematical rigor, probability, etc.
requisites: MATH 112 or MATH 112S or MATH 112Z or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Honors Linear Algebra
description: This course is the first half of the advanced math introductory sequence. It covers the basics of linear algebra: vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, and eigenvalues, with an emphasis on mathematical rigor. This class is for freshmen who scored a 5 on the Calculus AP BC exam.
requisites: AP Calculus BC or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Honors Vector Calculus
description: This course is the second half of the advanced mathematics introductory sequence. It covers the basics of vector calculus: differentiable mappings, differential forms, and integration theory.
requisites: MATH 275  or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: Rotating topics in mathematics. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: Rotating topics in mathematics. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Directed Study
description: May be repeated for credit, total credit not to exceed six hours. Cannot be used to meet course requirements for a Math major or minor. Topics vary by instructor.

title: Mathematics of Data Science
description: Mathematical foundations and efficient implementation of popular machine learning models. Topics include: regression and classification techniques, deep learning, model evaluation and practical Implementation.
requisites: (MATH 210 or MATH_OX 210 or MATH 211 or MATH_OX 211) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221) and (CS 170 or CS_OX 170 or MATH 170) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Numerical Analysis
description: Solution of linear and nonlinear systems of equations, interpolation, least-squares approximation, numerical integration, and differentiation.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (CS 170 or CS_OX 170 or MATH 170) or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Complex Variables
description: Analytic functions, elementary functions, integrals, power series, residues, and conformal mapping.
requisites: [(MATH 211 or MATH_OX211) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250)]   or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Abstract Vector Spaces
description: Axiomatic treatment of vector spaces, inner product spaces, minimal polynomials, Cayley Hamilton theorem, Jordan form, and bilinear forms.
requisites: MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH_OX 250Q or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Number Theory
description: This course introduces the basic concepts of algebraic and analytic number theory.  Topics include: congruence relations, the distribution of prime numbers, quadratic reciprocity, Diophantine equations, continued fractions, and generating functions.
requisites: MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH_OX 250Q or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Intro To Combinatorics
description: Combinations and permutations, counting techniques, recurrence relations, and generating functions. Block designs, finite planes, and coding theory. Introduction to graph theory.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Differential Geometry
description: Curves and surfaces in 3-space. The geometry of the Gauss map. Special surfaces. The intrinsic geometry of surfaces. Surfaces and computer graphics.
requisites: (MATH 211 or PHYS 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Mathematical Modeling
description: Principles of mathematical modeling; case studies using nonlinear ordinary differential equations, difference equations, and partial differential equations.
requisites: This course requires MATH 221 OR MATH_OX221 OR MATH 321 AND MATH 224 OR MATH 250 OR MATH_OX250 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Linear Optimization
description: Theory of linear programming, duality, optimal flows in networks, and mathematical programming.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (CS 170 or CS_OX 170 or MATH 170) or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Non-Linear Optimization
description: Nonlinear optimization problems arise in a wide range of applications, for example, in economics, physics, engineering, imaging. This introductory course covers a wide range of examples and both theory and practice of unconstrained and constrained optimization.
requisites: (MATH 211 or PHYS 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Partial Differential Equations
description: PDEs and their origin, classification of PDEs, analytical methods for the solution of PDEs, qualitative properties of the solutions, eigenvalue problems and introduction to numerical methods.
requisites: (MATH 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276) and (MATH 212 or MATH_OX 212) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: PDE's in Action
description: Partial Differential Equations (PDE's) are a formidable tool for describing real-life problems. In this course we use PDE's for cardiovascular problems and other real-life situations. Students will visit radiology labs and learn about image processing and numerical simulations in medicine.
requisites: (MATH 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276) and (MATH 212 or MATH_OX 212) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Mathematical Statistics I
description: Finite and continuous probability theory, distribution models (binomial, geometric, uniform, normal, Poisson, and exponential), the Chebyshev inequality, expectation and variance, moment generating functions, the central limit theorem, and applications.
requisites: MATH 210 or MATH_OX 210 or MATH 211 or PHYS 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Mathematical Statistics II
description: Fundamentals of statistical inference: estimation, properties of estimators, methods for comparing estimators, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, regression, and analysis of variance.
requisites: This course requires MATH 361 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: Rotating topics in mathematics. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: Rotating topics in mathematics. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Real Analysis I
description: Analysis of sets and functions in n-space which focuses on basic topological properties of sets as well as continuity and differentiation of functions. Topics: exterme value theorem, chain rule, and inverse function theorem.
requisites: (MATH 211 or PHYS 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Real Analysis II
description: This course is a continuation of Math 411 which focuses on integration and uniform convergence in n-space.  Topics include: Stoke's theorem, Fubini's theorem, Taylor's theorem, the Stone-Weierstrass theorem, and Sard's theorem.
requisites: This course requires MATH 211 AND MATH_OX211 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Abstract Algebra I
description: Groups (definition and examples), cosets, Lagrange's Theorem, symmetric and alternating groups, Cayley's Theorem, isomorphisms, Cauchy's Theorem, quotient groups and homomorphisms, and the action of a group on a set. Additional topics may include the Sylow Theorems.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Abstract Algebra II
description: Ring Theory and Field Theory: polynomial rings, unique factorization, Euclidean domains, splitting fields of polynomials, elements of Galois theory, finite fields.
requisites: This course requires MATH 421or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Mathematical Economics
description: Introduction to the use of calculus in economic analysis; comparative static problem and optimization theory; consideration of the mathematical techniques used in game theory.
requisites: (MATH 211 or MATH_OX 211 or MATH 276) and (ECON 201 or ECON_OX 201) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics in Mathematics
description: Rotating topics in mathematics. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Topics In Topology
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH_OX 250Q or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics In Topology
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH_OX 250Q or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Graph Theory
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics In Algebra
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics In Algebra
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) and (MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH 276) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics In Analysis
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH_OX 250Q or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics In Analysis
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
requisites: MATH 250 or MATH_OX 250 or MATH_OX 250Q or MATH 276 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Honors
description: Normally taken in student's last semester, up to a maximum of 4 credit hours.

title: Directed Research
description:
Students conduct directed or supervised research in support of a faculty member's
research project or agenda. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty
member is required.

title: Directed Reading
description:
Students study, read, and write on a topic under the direction or supervision of a faculty
member. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty member is required.

title: Independent Research
description:
Students conduct independent research in support of their own research agenda or
question with guidance from a faculty member. Permission of the department and a
supervising faculty member is required.

title: Computer Science Fundamentals
description: A general introduction to computer science including an overview of hardware systems, programming essentials, algorithm design, data handling, and networking. Not intended for students needing a programming background for further work in computer science.

title: Selected Programming Languages
description: Introductory course in a rotating series of computer languages. Please see current atlas for language offering.

title: Computing for Bioinformatics
description: An introduction to tools of computer science that are relevant to bioinformatics, with a focus on fundamental problems with sequence data. Practical topics will include Python programming, data management, and web services. Computational concepts are emphasized with examples from underlying biology.

title: Intro to Business Computing
description: Intro to tools and concepts of computer science most relevant to business (enterprise) computing and e-commerce. An intro to basic programming principles, page layout and visual interface design, client/server computing, simple techniques for accessing databases, and their algorithmic foundations.

title: Intro to Computer Science I
description: An introduction to Computer Science for students expecting to utilize serious computing in coursework, research, or employment. Emphasis is on computing concepts, programming principles, algorithm development and basic data structures, using the Java programming language and Unix operating system.

title: Intro.to Computer Science II
description:
A second course in Computer Science, focusing on intermediate programming. Emphasis is on proficiency in the use and implementation of data structures, algorithms for classical programming paradigms, and object oriented design and
programming with Java.
requisites: This course requires MUS 221 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Intro to Computer Science II
description: An accelerated version of the second course Computer Science for students with advanced preparation e.g. AP CS-A. Emphasis is on proficiency in the use of implementation of data structures, algorithms for classical programming paradigms, and object oriented design and programming with Java.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Rotating topics in computer science. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Prerequisites and co-requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Fresh Seminar:Computer Science
description: Topics will be anounced each semester when the course is offered.

title: Intro.Artificial Intelligence
description: Fundamentals, modern concepts, and practices in Artificial Intelligence including computational decision making, knowledge-based agents, propositional logic, search, heuristics, and machine learning. Assessment includes exams and hands-on projects based on real-world problems.
requisites: (MATH 111 or MATH_OX 111 or QTM 100 or QTM_OX 100) and (CS 110 or CS 170 or CS_OX 170) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Foundations of Comp.Science
description: An introductory course in the theory of Computer Science, focusing on analysis of discrete structures with applications. Emphasis is on developing familiarity with notation, computational acuity and creative problem solving skills.
requisites: (CS 170 or CS_OX 170) and (MATH 111 or MATH_OX 111) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Data Structures and Algorithms
description:
A third course in Computer Science, focusing on advanced programming. Emphasis is on mastery in the use and implementation of data structures and algorithms for classical programming paradigms, using the Java programming language and object oriented
design.
requisites: CS 171 or 171Z or CS_OX 171 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Comp.Arch./Machine Level Prog.
description: Introductory systems course in Computer Science, with a focus on high level computer architecture and assembler programming. Emphasis is on comprehension of von Neumann computer architecture, information encoding and data representation, and assembler equivalents of high level programming constructs.
requisites: This course requires CS 171 or  CS 171Z or CS_OX 171 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Rotating topics in computer science. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Computing, AI, Ethics, and Soc
description: Understanding ethical and societal concerns introduced by computing and AI into human life, including privacy, online influence and disinformation, information ownership and responsibility, fairness and bias in computer and AI technologies such as facial recognition and robotic systems.
requisites: CS 211 or CS 323 or CS 325 or CS 334 or CS 470 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Machine Learning Applications
description: Machine learning techniques and their use in solving problems from multiple real-world domains. Topics covered include data analytics, regression, classification, clustering, decision trees, and neural networks using Python libraries. Focuses on applications and use rather than algorithms or theory.

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: Foundations and problems of machine intelligence, application areas, representation of knowledge, constraint processing, AI programming languages, expert systems, design of an intelligent system.
requisites: (CS 224 or CS_OX 224) and CS 253 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Analysis of Algorithms
description: This course explores the formal underpinnings of computational complexity, and studies how to mathematically characterize the efficiency and running times of different computer algorithms.
requisites: (CS 170 or CS_OX 170) and (CS 171 or CS_OX 171) and (CS 224 or CS_OX 224) and CS 253, or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Computational Linguistics
description: This course will focus on the analysis of syntactic and semantic structures, ontologies and taxonomies, distributional semantics and discourse, as well as their applications in computational linguistics. Assignments will include advanced programming implementations.
requisites: This course requires CS 171 or  CS 171Z or CS_OX 171 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.

title: Machine Learning
description: This course will cover the underpinnings, algorithms, and practices that enable a computer to learn. Emphasis will be on fundamental theory and algorithms in statistical machine learning, and approaches to applying machine learning in a variety of domains.
requisites: (CS224 or CS_OX 224) and (CS 253 or CS_OX 253) and (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or MATH 275 or MATH 321) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Systems Programming
description: System programming topics are illustrated by the POSIX API to the Linux operating system. Topics include: file i/o, the TTY driver, window systems, processes, shared memory, message passing, semaphores, signals, and interrupt handlers.
requisites: CS 253 and CS 255 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Advanced Computer Architecture
description: A second course in computer organization and architecture. Emphasis is on combinatorial and sequential circuits, advanced characteristics of CPU and memory, and micro programming. Multiprocessors, GPUs and selected parallel algorithms will be discussed.
requisites: CS 253 and CS 255 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Computer Science Practicum
description: This course introduces basic concepts and techniques of software engineering, and applies these in the context of a semester-long group programming project.
requisites: CS 253 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Research Practicum in AI
description: This course guides students in developing the ability to conduct high-quality research in Artificial Intelligence (AI). Throughout the course, students will work on team projects, write research papers (both individually and in groups), peer-review papers from others, and give public presentations.
requisites: CS 325 or CS 334 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Research Practicum in AI
description: This course guides students in developing the ability to conduct high-quality research in Artificial Intelligence (AI). Throughout the course, students will work on team projects, write research papers (both individually and in groups), peer-review papers from others, and give public presentations.
requisites: CS 325 or CS 334 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Independ. Software Development
description: Prerequisite: permission of instructor. Credit, variable. An independent study course devoted to the development of software projects. Cannot be used to meet course requirements for a CS major.

title: Database Systems
description: Introduction to storage hierarchies, database models, consistency, reliability, and security issues. Query languages and their implementations, efficiency considerations, and compression and encoding techniques.
requisites: CS 253 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: Rotating topics in computer science. May be repeated for credit when the topic varies. Pre and co requisites depend on the topic offered.

title: Theory of Computing
description: Theory underlying computing concepts, including regular languages, pushdown automata, Turing machines, decidability of problems, time and space complexity and notions of P vs NP and NP-completeness.
requisites: CS 326 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Programming Languages
description: Explores the theory, design, & implementation of programming languages. Topics include syntax specification, parsing, formal semantics, functional & logic programming, pattern matching, backtracking, higher-order function, lambda calculus, continuation, parameter passing, meta-circular evaluation.
requisites: CS 224 and CS 253 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Structure of Info.Networks
description: This course studies connectedness of social, technological, and biological networks, covering models for information spread, formation of communities, the WWW graph, connection strength, and related topics, including methods to explain and exploit the structure of information and social networks.
requisites: (CS 224 or CS_OX 224) and (CS 253 or CS_OX 253) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Information Visualization
description: In this course, students 1) will become acquainted with fundamental theories in perceptual psychology that drive visualization design, 2) will be introduced to basic principles of HCI which inform evaluation of interactive visualizations, and 3) will use D3 to develop interactive visualizations.
requisites: CS 253 or CS_OX 253 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Computer Vision
description: This course is an introduction to concepts and applications in computer vision. It discusses cameras and projection models, and the core computer vision applications of visual recognition tasks. It examines low-level image processing methods and the deep learning methods for solving these tasks.
requisites: CS 334 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Text Proc. w. Neural Networks
description: This course offers an exploration into the fundamentals of text processing techniques and their integration with modern neural network architectures. Emphasis is placed on a range of neural networks. Students will learn how to use different types of neural networks for text processing tasks.
requisites: CS 325 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Deep Learning
description: Theoretical and practical aspects of deep learning; classification; feedforward networks; back propagaton; regularization; and convolutional, recurrent, and recursive neural networks.
requisites: CS 334 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Operating Systems
description: The structure and organization of computer operating systems. Process, memory, and I/O management; device drivers, exception handling, and interprocess communication. Students write an operating system as a course-long project.
requisites: CS 350 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Computer Security
description: Understanding offense is key to better cyberdefense. We focus on advanced vulnerabilities, exploits and defense technologies. We teach the hacker mindset, ethics as well as C and assembly.
requisites: CS 350 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Intro to Computer Networking
description: Intro to computer networks based on internal structure using the OSI layer model. Topics include: physical layer, data link layer, the network layer (routing algorithms, IP protocol, tunneling), and transport layer (UDP and TCP protocols, NS2 network simulation). Berkeley socket and pthreads APIs.
requisites: CS 350 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Compiler Construction
description: Syntax, semantics and pragmatics of computer programming languages, lexical analysis and parsing, code generation, and optimization. Design and implementation of a semester-long compiler project for a simple imperative language.
requisites: CS 326 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Quantum Computing&Information
description: An introduction to qubits, quantum gates, quantum circuits, quantum key distribution, quantum teleportation, quantum dense coding, Grover's search algorithm, Shor's factoring algorithm, quantum entanglement and Bell's theorem, and quantum error correction.
requisites: PHYS 220 or MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.

title: Data Mining
description: Data mining techniques including data pre-processing, data warehousing and management, dimension reduction, clustering, similarity search, graphical models, spatiotemporal data mining.
requisites: CS 224 and CS 253 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Computing Methods in Economics
description: This course introduces students to the use of advanced computer science techniques for the economic analysis of observational data. It covers multi-processing programming for economic policy simulation, web scraping for sentiment analysis,  and network data and social interaction models.
requisites: ECON 320 & CS 334 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisites.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies. Pre/co-requisites vary with topic.

title: Topics in Computer Science
description: May be repeated for credit when topic varies. Pre/co-requisites vary with topic.

title: Honors
description: Enrollment limited to departmental majors invited to participate in the Honors Program.

title: Directed Research
description: Students conduct directed or supervised research in support of a faculty member's research project or agenda. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty member is required.Three combined credits of CS 497R, CS 498R and CS 499R may be used to fulfill a maximum of one 400-level elective for Computer Science majors.

title: Directed Reading
description: Students study, read, and write on a topic under the direction or supervision of a faculty member. Permission of the department and a supervising faculty member is required. Three combined credits of CS 497R, CS 498R and CS 499R may be used to fulfill a maximum of one 400-level elective for Computer Science majors.

title: Independent Research
description:
Students conduct independent research in support of their own research
agenda or question with guidance from a faculty member. Permission of the
department and a supervising faculty member is required. Three combined credits of CS 497R, CS 498R and CS 499R may be used to fulfill a maximum of one 400-level elective for Computer Science majors.
